and the provisions of sections 3.07.014 through 3.07.022 of this article.
(c) Base flood elevation data shall be generated for subdivision proposals and other proposed development
including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions which is greater than 50 lots or 5 acres,
whichever is lesser, if not otherwise provided pursuant to section 3.07.007 or section 3.07.014(8) of this article.
(d) All subdivision proposals including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall
have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood hazards.
(e) All subdivision proposals including the placement of manufactured home parks and subdivisions shall
have public utilities and facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems located and constructed to
minimize or eliminate flood damage.
Sec. 3.07.020 Standards for areas of shallow flooding (AO/AH zones)
Located within the areas of special flood hazard established in section 3.07.007, are areas designated as shallow
flooding. These areas have special flood hazards associated with flood depths of 1 to 3 feet where a clearly
defined channel does not exist, where the path of flooding is unpredictable, and where velocity flow may be
evident. Such flooding is characterized by ponding or sheet flow; therefore, the following provisions apply:
(1) All new construction and substantial improvements of residential structures have the lowest
floor (including basement) elevated to or above the base flood elevation or the highest adjacent grade
at least as high as the depth number specified in feet on the community's FIRM (at least 2 feet if no
depth number is specified).
(2) All new construction and substantial improvements of nonresidential structures:
(A) Have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated to or above the base flood elevation
or the highest adjacent grade at least as high as the depth number specified in feet on the
community's FIRM (at least 2 feet if no depth number is specified); or
(B) Together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities be designed so that below the base
specified flood depth in an AO zone, or below the base flood elevation in an AH zone, level the
structure is watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and with
structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads of
effects of buoyancy.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 152/652
(3) A registered professional engineer or architect shall submit a certification to the floodplain
administrator that the standards of this section, as proposed in section 3.07.015 are satisfied.
(4) Require within zones AH or AO adequate drainage paths around structures on slopes, to guide
floodwaters around and away from proposed structures.
Sec. 3.07.021 Floodways
Floodways - located within areas of special flood hazard established in section 3.07.007, are areas designated as
floodways. Since the floodway is an extremely hazardous area due to the velocity of floodwaters which carry
debris, potential projectiles and erosion potential, the following provisions shall apply:
(1) Encroachments are prohibited, including fill, new construction, substantial improvements and
other development within the adopted regulatory floodway unless it has been demonstrated through
hydrologic and hydraulic analyses performed in accordance with standard engineering practice that
the proposed encroachment would not result in any increase in flood levels within the community
during the occurrence of the base flood discharge.
(2) If subsection (1) above is satisfied, all new construction and substantial improvements shall
comply with all applicable flood hazard reduction provisions of sections 3.07.014 through 3.07.022.
(3) Under the provisions of 44 CFR chapter 1, section 65.12, of the National Flood Insurance
Program regulations, a community may permit encroachments within the adopted regulatory
floodway that would result in an increase in base flood elevations, provided that the community first
completes all of the provisions required by section 65.12.
Sec. 3.07.022 Penalties for noncompliance
Failure to comply with any of its requirements (including violations of conditions and safeguards established in
connection with conditions) shall be punished in accordance with section 1.01.009 of this code.
(Ordinance 08-09-684 adopted 10/14/08)
ARTICLE 3.08 SIGNS*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 3.08.001 Authority and applicability
The provisions of this article are adopted pursuant to Texas Local Government Code chapter 216 and the city
charter. The terms and conditions of this article shall apply to signs located within the city and its extraterritorial
jurisdiction. (Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.01, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.002 Purpose and scope
This article is enacted to provide uniform standards for the location, spacing, height, lighting, and other
regulations of signs within the city. The purpose of this article is to protect the health, safety, welfare,
convenience and enjoyment of the general public and to protect the public from injury, which may be caused by
the unregulated construction of signs. It is the intent of these regulations to achieve the following:
(1) Enhance the economic value of the landscape by avoiding visual clutter that is potentially
harmful to property values and business opportunities;
(2) Promote the safety of persons and property by providing that signs do not create a hazard, due
to collapse, fire, collision, weather or decay;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 153/652
(3) Protect the safety and efficiency of the city's transportation network by reducing the confusion
or distraction to motorists and enhancing motorists' ability to see pedestrians, obstacles, other
vehicles, and traffic signs;
(4) Enhance the impression of the city which is conveyed to tourists and visitors;
(5) Protect adjacent and nearby properties from the impact of lighting, size, heights and locations
of signs;
(6) Preserve, protect and enhance areas of historical, architectural, scenic and aesthetic value,
regardless of whether they be cultural, natural or manmade; and
(7) Encourage the removal of off-premises signs from designated scenic, cultural, architectural or
historic districts and corridors.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.02, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.003 Relationship to zoning ordinance
No regulation contained herein shall be deemed as being controlled or regulated by the zoning ordinance. The
only relationship with the zoning ordinance shall be of a locational nature designating within which zoning
district specified sign types are permitted. The zoning board of adjustment shall not have authority relative to
relief from the regulations in this article, unless specifically authorized by this article. (Ordinance 08-08-671, ex.
A, sec. 1.03, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.004 Definitions
(a) General sign definitions. For the purpose of this article, the following words shall have the following
definitions ascribed to them:
Building official. The building official or other city employee designated by the building official or city manager.
City. The City of Royse City, Texas.
City manager. The city manager or other city employee designated by the city manager.
Corner lot. A lot which has at least two adjacent sides abutting for their full lengths on a public street or rightof-
way, provided that the interior angle at the intersection of such two sides is less than one hundred thirty-five
(135) degrees.
CZO. The City's Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance found in exhibit A to chapter 14, as it currently exists or
may be amended.
Developed. A developed property is a nonresidential property for which a certificate of occupancy has been
issued by the building official to occupy a building on the property or a residential property for which a
certificate of final acceptance has been issued by the city.
Height of sign. The distance measured vertically at 90 degrees from the ground at the base of the sign to the
highest projection of the sign and its support structure. For a wall sign, the measurement is from the bottom edge
of the sign to the highest projection of the sign and its support structure. Signs placed on mounds of earth or
berms shall be measured from the base of the mound or berm.
Lot frontage. That dimension of a lot or portion of a lot abutting on a street.
Multi-tenant site. Consists of a commercial development that has multiple commercial users located in a
shopping center and also may consist of a single large lot or multiple lots with the same subdivision name or
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 154/652
multiple lots which are depicted on the same plat, concept plan or site plan. A multi-tenant site is generally
united through common building architecture, color, and materials, landscaping and parking.
Notice. Notice required by this article shall be sufficient if it is affected by personal delivery, registered or
certified mail, return receipt requested, and/or depositing the notice with the United States mail.
On-premises/off-premises. The term “on-premises” means a sign which is designed to be used to attract attention
to activities, commodities, services or other endeavors offered for display, purchase, or service on the premises
on which the sign is located. The term “off-premises” means a sign which is designed to be used to attract
attention to activities, commodities, services or other endeavors offered for display, purchase, or service which
are not located on the premises on which the sign is located.
Person. Any person, firm, partnership, corporation, company, organization or business entity of any kind.
Prohibited sign. Any sign listed in section 3.08.012 herein, signs that do not comply with this or other applicable
ordinances, and signs that are otherwise prohibited.
Public view. A view from any public or city right-of-way or access easement.
Sign. Any form of publicity or advertising which directs attention to an individual, business, commodity, service,
activity, or product, by means of words, lettering, parts of letters, figures, numerals, phrases, sentences,
emblems, devices, trade names or trademarks, or other pictorial matter designed to convey such information and
displayed by means of print, bills, posters, panels, or other devices erected on an open framework, or attached or
otherwise applied to stakes, posts, poles, trees, buildings, or other structures or supports. This definition shall
also include any device, fixture, placard, or structure that uses any color, form, graphic, illumination, symbol, or
writing to advertise, announce the purpose of a person or entity, or communicate information of any kind to the
public. All structural elements, framework, poles, columns, or other supportive devices shall be included in the
definition; however, shall not be subject to the measurement of the sign face.
Sign box. The area of sign face consisting of a horizontal distance and a vertical distance which defines the
dimension to be used to calculate the size of the sign.
Sign wall (primary and secondary walls). The wall of the building upon which a sign may be mounted. The
primary wall of the building is any wall facing the street and/or permitting primary access to the public or
customers. A secondary wall is that wall that is determined to be of secondary importance to the business or
establishment occupying the premises and shall include any wall not designated as a primary wall.
Static display. The use of displays or devices for the purpose of drawing or attracting attention to a location, site,
business or activity.
Street. Any dedicated public thoroughfare that affords the principal means of access to abutting property.
Undeveloped. An undeveloped property is a property for which a certificate of occupancy has not been issued by
the building official on the property or a residential property for which a certificate of final acceptance has not
been issued by the city.
Vehicle. Any device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported.
(b) Sign type definitions. For the purpose of this article, the following words shall have the following
definitions ascribed to them:
Awning. An awning sign is a sign which is applied to, attached, or painted on an awning or other roof-like cover,
intended for protection from the weather or as a decorative embellishment, projecting from a wall or roof of a
structure over a window, walk, door, or the like.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 155/652
Bandit sign. Any sign posted on a utility pole, street sign or other street furniture or a sign posted in violation of
this article in the public right-of-way having six (6) square feet or less of advertising area and made of vinyl,
paper, cloth or fabric, polyboard, coroplas, corrugated plastic, poster board, plastic core, cardboard or plywood
including signs with wood or wire framing, posts or stakes. No sign owned or placed by the city or a public
utility shall be considered a bandit sign.
Banner sign. A banner sign is a sign having characters, letters, or illustrations applied to plastic, cloth, canvas, or
other light fabric, with the only purpose of such non-rigid material being for background.
Billboard. A large sign, generally supported by a metal frame and consisting of two parallel sign faces oriented
in opposite directions, used for the display of posters, printed or painted advertisements that generally direct
attention to goods, merchandise, entertainment, or services conducted, sold, or offered at a location other than
the premises on which the sign is located.
Canopy sign. A canopy sign is a sign that is applied to, attached, or painted on a canopy or other roof-like cover
over gasoline fuel pumps, intended for protection from the weather or as a decorative embellishment.
Electronic sign. A sign that is utilized year round, but the copy is changed periodically, advertising different
specials associated with retail sales. This does not include a portable sign that may have changeable copy but is
not permanently placed or located at a specific site. However, it does include the following signs:
(1) Message board sign. Any sign or portion of a sign that uses changing lights to form a nonpictorial
message in text format wherein the sequence of messages and rate of change is
electronically programmed and can be modified by electronic process.
(2) Electronic graphic display sign. A sign or portion thereof that displays electronic, static
images, static graphics or static pictures, with or without information, defined by a small number of
matrix elements using different combinations of light emitting diodes (LED's), fiber optics, light
bulbs or other illumination devices within the display and where the image sequence is accomplished
immediately or by means of fade, repixalization, or dissolve modes.
(3) Video display sign. A sign capable of changing its message or background in a manner or
method of display characterized by motion or pictorial imagery, which may or may not include text
and depicts action or a special effect to indicate movement.
Flags. A flag is a piece of fabric attached to a staff or cord on one end and used as a symbol of a nation, state,
political subdivision, or organization.
Human sign. A human sign is a sign held by or attached to a human for the purposes of advertising or otherwise
drawing attention to an individual, business, commodity, service, activity, or product. A person dressed in
costume for the purpose of advertising or otherwise drawing attention to an individual, business, commodity,
service, activity, or product shall also be construed as a human sign.
Inflatable sign. An inflatable sign is a sign manufactured of plastic, cloth, canvas, or other light fabric and
inflated with air.
Instructional sign. An instructional sign is a sign that provides instruction, information, or direction to the
general public. The sole purpose of an instructional sign is to provide instruction, information, or direction to the
general public that is essential to the health, safety, and public welfare of the community. An instructional sign
shall contain no other message, copy, announcement, or decoration other than the essential instruction,
information, or direction and shall not advertise or otherwise draw attention to an individual, business,
commodity, service, activity, or product. Such signs shall include, but are not limited to, the following: signs
identifying a property's street address, restrooms, public telephones, handicap parking spaces, reserved parking
spaces, freeze warning, no trespassing, no dumping, no loitering, and construction entrance and/or exit signs.
Signs erected by the municipal, state or federal government for the purpose of public instruction, warning, street
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 156/652
or highway designation, control of traffic and similar uses incidental to the public interests shall be considered
instructional signs. An instructional sign also includes signs of a warning, directive or instructional nature
erected by a public utility company that operates under a franchise agreement with the city.
Menu board sign. A menu board sign is a sign erected in conjunction with a use that incorporates a drivethrough
or drive-in and generally used to provide service and/or product options and pricing for customers who
remain in their vehicles.
Monument. A permanent ground sign generally constructed out of brick, stone, or cast concrete foundation
across the entire base of the structure; a monument sign shall not exceed seven (7) feet in height, measured from
the finished grade to the top of the sign. The distance from the ground to the base of any structure or framework
containing the sign face shall not exceed 18-inches.
Pole sign. A sign that is suspended with a clearance of at least ten feet from the bottom of the sign and is on a
single freestanding column, pole, upright, or brace placed in or upon the ground and is not a part of a building.
Political signs. A sign:
(1) Relating to the election of a person to a public office;
(2) Relating to a political party;
(3) Relating to a matter to be voted upon at an election called by a public body; or
(4) Containing primarily a political message.
Portable signs. Signs designed or intended to be relocated from time to time, whether or not it is permanently
attached to a building or structure, or is located on the ground. Portable signs include signs on wheels or on
portable or mobile structures, such as, among other things, trailers, skids, tent signs, A-frame, or T-shaped signs
and similar devices, and airborne signs.
Projecting signs. A projecting sign is a sign attached to and projecting out from a building face or wall more
than twelve (12) inches, generally at a right angle to the building.
Roof sign. A roof sign is any sign erected, constructed or maintained on the roof of a building.
Sandwich board sign. An advertising or business ground sign constructed in such a manner as to form an “A” or
a tent-like shape, hinged or not hinged at the top, each angular face held at an appropriate distance by a
supporting member. Used as a temporary movable sign to be placed along a sidewalk or in pedestrian travel
areas.
Sidewalk signs. A sign that is used to advertise daily specials.
Subdivision entry monument signs. A sign placed at the entrance of a subdivision for the purpose of identifying
the name of the subdivision; may incorporate landscaping, public art, or water features as part of the design of
the sign.
Temporary sign. A sign that is not permanently fixed to the ground or structure that is permanently fixed to the
ground; may include signs that have wood or metal posts that are inserted in the ground with no structural
support or base upon which it sets (2"x4" posts and t-posts); also includes signs placed on structures with rollers,
wheels, or skids which are not attached to the ground or a structure that is not permanently fixed to the ground.
Wall signs. A wall sign is a sign painted on or erected parallel to and extending not more than twelve (12) inches
from the facade of any building to which it is attached, supported throughout its entire length by the building
face. A wall sign may include neon tubing attached directly to a wall surface when forming a border for the
subject matter or when forming letters, logos, or pictorial designs, except on property zoned downtown district,
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 157/652
as defined in the CZO. This definition shall not include painted on murals. Murals shall not include the
advertising of businesses or services located on the site. Murals are not subject to the wall sign regulations
contained herein.
Wind device signs. With the exception of inflatable signs and flags, a wind device sign is a pennant, streamer,
spinners, balloon, inflatable object or similar device made of cloth, canvas, plastic, or any flexible material that
moves or is designed to move freely in the wind, with or without a frame or other supporting structure, used for
the purpose of advertising or drawing attention to a business, commodity, service, sale, or product.
Window signs. A window sign is a sign that is visible from public access and that is permanently attached,
painted, placed, or affixed in or on a window; that displays the business name and logo. “Open” signs (max 2 sq.
ft.), directional signs (push/pull), no smoking, etc. (max. 36 sq. inches).
Wood frame signs. A wood frame sign is a temporary sign that is generally used to advertise a new building,
opening dates, leasing opportunities, and/or to identify the property owner, architect, contractor, engineer,
landscape architect, or financier engaged in the design, construction or improvement of the premises on which
the sign is located. Wood frame signs are also used to advertise sales and zoning information of property. In no
case shall a wood frame sign contain information pertaining to off-premises uses. Although wood frame signs
are generally constructed of wood, the definition does not exclude metal or plastic signs used for the same
purpose.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.04, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.005 Appellate procedures and request for minor relief from regulations
(a) Any person aggrieved by an order, decision or determination made by the building official made pursuant
to this article is entitled to an appeal of such order, decision, or determination, to an administration adjudication
hearing pursuant to the administrative hearing process as established in article 7.02. All appeals will be
conducted in accordance with the administrative hearing process.
(1) Limitations of appeal.
(A) An application for an appeal shall be based solely on a claim that the building official has
incorrectly interpreted or applied this code.
(B) The administrative hearing officer shall have no authority to waive, alter or amend any
requirements of this article.
(2) Ancillary proceedings.
(A) An appeal filed pursuant to subsection (a) of this section shall have no effect on the
ability of the city to enforce any rule, ordinance, law, or police regulation and shall not stay any
proceedings initiated by the city.
(B) The appellate procedures set forth in this article are administrative remedies available to
any person aggrieved by an order, decision or determination made by the building official.
(b) Any person may request an administration adjudication hearing to determine whether the administrative
hearing officer should grant minor relief in the form of a waiver from the regulations described in this article.
Any waivers granted shall be in accordance with the following conditions:
(1) Waivers may only be granted for minor variations to the height, area, location, number of signs,
and sign lighting.
(2) The administrative adjudication hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the
administrative hearing process as established in article 7.02, except that the fee for requesting a
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 158/652
hearing to grant minor relief shall be accompanied by a fee of $150.00 that is nonrefundable.
(3) Before the tenth (10th) day of the date of the administrative adjudication hearing, written notice
of the hearing shall be published in the official newspaper of the city, stating the time and place of
such hearing.
(4) Prior to granting any waiver from the regulations, the administrative hearing officer shall make
an affirmative finding of at least one of the following conditions:
(A) Special circumstances applicable to the subject property, including size, shape,
topography, street frontage, location or surrounding land use exist as to justify a waiver from
the regulations; or
(5) Section 7.02.014, Judicial Review, of the administrative hearing process does not apply to
hearings to grant minor relief in the form of a waiver from the regulations described in this article.
(c) National/regional franchise designs, which cannot be readily altered, may be approved administratively by
staff. However, administrative staff may defer the approval of the waiver request to the administrative hearing
process if in the opinion of the administrative staff the waiver from the regulations are significant and contrary to
the spirit of the sign ordinance.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.07, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.006 License required
(a) No person shall install, erect or maintain any sign, except banner signs and all signs for which a permit is
not required, or contract for such service, until such person has applied to the building official for a license to
install, erect and/or maintain signs, and until such license has been approved and issued. The building official
shall approve or deny an application for a license within thirty (30) days of the city's receipt of the application. A
license will be issued if all requirements of city ordinances are met. A license is valid twelve (12) months from
the date of issuance.
(b) The license of any sign contractor may be canceled by the building official, when such contractor
repeatedly violates the requirements of this article. Conviction in court, whether appealed or not, on two (2)
violations over a period of twelve (12) months, shall constitute evidence of repeated violation. Any license thus
canceled shall not be renewed for such contractor or anyone operating in concert with such contractor until all
such violations have been corrected. Upon correction of violations, the contractor's license may be renewed upon
furnishing the bond required in section 3.08.007.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.08, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.007 Sign contractor bond required
(a) No license for the installation, erection and/or maintenance of signs shall be issued to any person nor shall
any person install, erect or maintain any sign, except banner signs and all signs for which a permit is not
required, or medium of display or advertising, electric or otherwise, until such person has provided proof of
general liability insurance in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) to the building official
or filed with the city clerk a surety bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). Such bond shall be
approved by the city manager and shall be conditioned for the installation and erection of signs in accordance
with the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state, and shall provide for the indemnification of the city for
any and all damages or liability which may accrue against it by reason of faulty installation, erection,
demolition, repair, removal or defects in, or collapse of, any sign for a period of one (1) year after erection or for
such period of time that such sign is maintained or serviced by or under the direction of the maker of such bond,
whichever is longer. Such bond shall further provide for the indemnification of any person who shall, while upon
public property or in any public place, incur damage for which the principle named in the bond is legally liable.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 159/652
(b) When any sign contractor's license has been canceled as provided in section 3.08.006(b), such license shall
not be renewed until the contractor furnishes an additional bond in the amount of five thousand dollars
($5,000.00) guaranteeing compliance with the provisions of this article, which bond shall be for a period of two
(2) years following renewal of the license.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.09, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.008 Inspection
The building official reserves the right to perform an inspection of all signs. The purpose of the inspection is to
ensure that the sign has been constructed in accordance with this article, any other applicable ordinances, and the
applicable permits. The method and time of such inspections shall be determined by the building official.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.10, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.009 General sign specifications and design
(a) Compliance with Comprehensive Zoning Ordinance, International Building Code, National Electrical
Code, and other ordinances. All sign structures shall comply with the CZO, the currently adopted International
Building Code, the National Electrical Code, and other city ordinances, as they currently exist or may be
amended. If the standards as described herein are more restrictive, then the provisions of this article shall apply.
(b) Visibility. All signs shall observe all visibility requirements. Signs shall not be placed within visibility
triangles, corner clips, and V.A.M. (visibility, access, and maintenance) easements as defined in the city's
thoroughfare and circulation design requirements or other documents.
(c) Signs posted in specified areas. Unless otherwise permitted within this article, no person shall post or
cause to be posted, attach or maintain any sign upon:
(1) Any city-owned property or right-of-way without the written permission of the city manager or
his/her designated representative;
(2) Any utility easement. Should a property owner be able to demonstrate to the city engineer
and/or franchise utility company that there is no other viable location for a sign other than a utility
easement, a sign may be located within the utility easement subject to written approval from the city
engineer and/or franchise utility company and subject to the providing of a letter to the city releasing
the city of any liability for repair or replacement of a sign damaged by work occurring within the
utility easement;
(3) Any tree, utility pole or structure, street sign, rail or any fence;
(4) Any fence, railing or wall, unless otherwise provided herein;
(5) Any sidewalk within the right-of-way or a sidewalk easement, curb, gutter, or street, except for
house numbers or fire lane designation.
(d) Signs attached to fire escapes. No sign shall be attached in any manner to any fire escape or to the
supporting members of any fire escape, nor shall it be guyed to or supported by any part of the fire escape.
(e) Accumulation of rainwater. All signs shall be constructed so as to prevent the accumulation of rainwater in
the sign.
(f) Location near telephone cable, power line, or streetlight. No sign shall be erected nearer than two (2) feet
from any telephone cable, power line or any streetlight standard.
(g) Signs not to block or interfere with exits or windows and pedestrian and vehicular traffic. No sign shall be
so erected as to block, partially block, or interfere in any way with a required means of exit from any building
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 160/652
nor with any window. No sign shall block, interfere, or otherwise hinder pedestrian or vehicular traffic on a
public sidewalk, a public thoroughfare, a fire lane easement, or a driveway required to access parking.
(h) Glass signs over public property. Signs constructed of glass or other materials which may shatter upon
impact are prohibited over public right-of-way.
(i) Identification marking required. All banner, wood frame, panel, and pole signs permitted after adoption of
this article shall have attached, written, or painted in a weatherproof manner and in a conspicuous place thereon,
in letters not less than one (1) inch in height, the date of erection and the permit number of the sign.
(j) Assumed wind load for design purposes and dead load requirements. For the purposes of design of
structural members in signs, an assumed wind load of twenty (20) pounds per square foot shall be used, except
that for any type of pole sign allowed under this article shall have an assumed wind load of thirty (30) pounds
per square foot. All permanent signs shall be constructed to receive dead loads as required by the city's building
code as it exists or may be amended.
(k) Multiple signs on a property or building. The permitting of a sign on a property or building shall not
preclude the permitting of other types of signs on a property or building unless the signs are expressly prohibited
herein.
(l) Exemptions. Signs located within a building with the exception of window signs shall not be regulated by
this article.
(m) Condition of signs. All signs and support structures shall be maintained in good condition and there shall
be no visible indications of rust, oxidation, deterioration or other unsightly conditions.
(n) Signs on vacant buildings. No sign shall be permitted to remain on any vacant building, except a sign
pertaining to the lease or sale of the building, or a sign which is under lease from an owner or his agent, when
such sign is maintained by a person operating under his own bond.
(o) Merchandise displays. No person shall suspend from any building, or pole, structure, sidewalk, parkway,
driveway, parking area, or fuel pump island any goods, wares, merchandise or other advertising object or
structure for the purpose of advertising such items, other than a sign as defined, regulated and prescribed by this
article, except as otherwise allowed by any city ordinance.
(p) Balloons or other floating devices. For any period exceeding two weeks in any six months, no person shall
erect, maintain or permit the erection of any balloon or other floating device anchored to the ground, vehicle,
structure, or any other fixed object for the purpose of advertising or drawing attention to a business, commodity,
service, sale, or product.
(q) Additional prohibited signs.
(1) Skylights and searchlights, except for temporary event lighting occurring prior to 10:00 p.m.
within illumination levels contained in the Illuminating Engineering Society of North America
Lightning Handbook, as it exists or may be amended, to ensure safe illumination levels;
(2) Appendages to primary signs which have flashing, blinking, or traveling lights;
(3) Any sign which emits audible sound, odor, or visible matter;
(4) Any sign not referenced within or governed by this article;
(5) Any sign erected without a permit, either prior to or after the adoption of this article, if a permit
was required; and
(6) Any sign erected in or over a public right-of-way, unless permitted within this article.

https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 161/652
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.11, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.010 Sign area computation
The following principles shall control the computation of sign area for signs located within the corporate limits
of the city. Where a particular configuration, shape, or style of sign is not covered within this regulation the
computation of the sign shall be approved by the city representative designated to review and approve sign
applications. The configuration of the sign box may be proposed by the applicant but shall be totally at the
discretion of the city representative designated to review and approve sign applications. Any appeal to the
decision of this representative shall be in accordance with the procedure for appeal as provided herein.
(1) Measurement of detached signs. The sign area for a detached on-premises sign shall be the area
included within vertical and horizontal line projections (sign box) of the furthermost points of any
logos, letters, or other symbols, composed of the total area of the message, and any border, trim or
surface upon which the message is displayed. One sign area will be calculated for a detached sign no
matter how the message is displayed, unless otherwise approved by the city representative designated
to review and approve sign applications. The sign structure shall not be included in the sign box
unless there is a sign displayed thereon.
(2) Measurement of attached signs. The sign area for an attached on-premises sign shall be the area
included within the vertical and horizontal line projection (sign box) of any logos, letters, or other
symbols intended to be read together, composed of the total area of the message and any border, trim
or surface upon which the message is displayed. There may be several sign boxes on the wall or a
building, depending upon how a sign is displayed.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 162/652
NOTE: Two sq. ft. of sign area for each one linear foot of storefront or tenant front.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.12, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.011 Miscellaneous sign regulations
(a) Menu board signs.
(1) A menu board sign may be utilized on a nonresidential district which is permitted by zoning
regulations in a residentially zoned district.
(2) Minimum front yard setback is twenty-five (25) feet from the property line.
(3) Drive-through menu board and pre-order signs:
(A) Shall be supported from the grade to the bottom of the sign having or appearing to have a
solid base.
(B) The design, materials, and finish of a drive-through menu board shall match those of the
building(s) on the same lot.
(C) Two drive-through menu board signs are permitted per drive-through use on a lot.
(4) Drive-in menu board:
(A) Shall be supported from the grade to the bottom of the sign having or appearing to have a
solid base. If the drive-in stalls are covered by a canopy, the drive-in menu board signs may be
attached directly to the canopy support columns.
(B) The design, materials, and finish of a drive-through menu board shall match those of the
building(s) on the same lot.
(C) Two drive-in menu board signs are permitted per ordering station.
(D) The maximum area of a drive-in menu board sign is nine (9) square feet with a maximum
height of six (6) feet.
(b) Bonus setback for wall sign. Wall signs that are setback from the right-of-way may receive additional area
bonus. Wall signs that are setback from the public right-of-way over one hundred fifty feet can increase the
maximum primary wall signage area by twenty-five percent and increase an additional twenty-five percent for
every additional one hundred feet of setback; up to a maximum of 200% of the allowed sign area (i.e. 20% of the
primary wall area) at four hundred fifty feet.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 163/652
(1) Over 150 feet setback = 125% of allowed sign area or 12.5% of primary wall area.
(2) Over 250 feet setback = 150% of allowed sign area or 15% of primary wall area.
(3) Over 350 feet setback = 175% of allowed sign area or 17.5% of primary wall area.
(4) Over 450 feet setback = 200% of allowed sign area or 20% of primary wall area.
(5) Under no circumstance shall the primary wall signage, including bonus area, exceed 400 square
feet of wall size.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.17, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.012 Prohibited signs
(a) Except where expressly allowed by these sign regulations, the following signs and activities are
prohibited:
(1) Off-premises signs.
(2) Billboard signs.
(3) Wind device signs.
(4) Bandit signs.
(5) Handwritten signs.
(6) Portable signs.
(7) Neon signs, except for “open” and “closed” signs, unless otherwise provided for by section
3.08.005(b) or section 3.08.021.
(b) The city manager may authorize the use of off-premises signs and/or bandit signs by developers and
homebuilders who are active participants in the city's sign plaza program. If a developer and/or homebuilder
have a sign panel on a sign plaza structure and the developer and/or homebuilder believe that the sign plaza
structure(s) do not adequately provide directions and information on their developments, then the developer
and/or homebuilder may request that the city manager authorize the use of off-premises signs and/or bandit
signs. Upon a request by a developer and/or homebuilder, the city manager may authorize the use of offpremises
signs and/or bandit signs if in the city manager's opinion the use of off-premises signs and/or bandit
signs by the developer and/or homebuilder are warranted. Such authorization shall be issued in writing by the
city manager and shall include information on sign numbers, locations, types, sizes, durations, and other factors
the city manager deems necessary.
(Ordinance 12-04-892 adopted 4/24/12)
Sec. 3.08.013 Removal/impoundment of prohibited signs
(a) All signs listed in section 3.08.012 and other prohibited or noncompliant signs shall be considered a public
nuisance and are prohibited by this article. Upon identification of any prohibited sign, the building official shall
provide written notification of the violation to the owner of the property on which the prohibited sign is located
and/or the permittee of the sign.
(1) The building official shall provide written notification by certified mail to the owner of the sign
regarding the violation. The notification shall state that the offending sign shall be repaired or
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 164/652
removed by the owner, agent or person having beneficial use of the land, building or structure upon
which such sign is located.
(2) The owner of the sign in violation shall be permitted 10 calendar days to respond to the
building official regarding the notification of violation.
(3) Following the 10-day period of response, the owner of the sign in violation shall be notified
that if the sign is not removed or repaired, a citation may be issued and the city may resort to any
civil remedy available to remove or repair the sign, up to and including impoundment. The owner of
the sign in violation shall have 30 days to bring the sign into compliance or remove the sign. If any
sign is determined to present an immediate danger to public health, safety, or welfare, the city shall
remove it immediately. An extension of the 30-day period may be granted upon demonstration of the
sign owner of merit upon the discretion of the city manager. The city manager may defer such
decision to the appellate procedures as defined in section 3.08.005, at his/her discretion.
(4) Signs authorized by a sign permit with an expiration date shall be removed promptly upon the
date of expiration. Signs remaining after the date of expiration shall be deemed prohibited. The sign
permit listing the expiration date shall be considered adequate notice of violation.
(b) It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation receiving such written notice or having an expired
permit to fail to comply with the direction of the notice. In the event of failure to comply with such notice
provided under subsection (a) above, the building official is hereby authorized to cause the removal and
impoundment of such sign. Any expenses incident thereto shall be the responsibility of the owner, agent or
person having beneficial use of the land, building or structure upon which such sign was located.
(c) If a sign is placed within the public right-of-way or on a city-owned property in violation of this article, the
sign may be immediately removed and impounded.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.19, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.014 Recovery of impounded signs
(a) Impounded signs may be recovered by the owner within fifteen (15) days from the date of the written
notification of impoundment by paying a fee as follows:
(1) A fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for signs which are six (6) square feet or less in area,
plus any expenses incurred by the city in removing the sign.
(2) A fee of four hundred dollars ($400.00) for signs which are larger than six (6) square feet in
area, plus any expenses incurred by the city in removing the sign.
(b) Signs not recovered within fifteen (15) days of impoundment may be disposed of by the city in any
manner it shall elect.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.20, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.015 Neglected sign
(a) A neglected sign is a sign which contains missing panels, burned out lights, missing letters, rust, loose
parts, or is faded from its natural color.
(b) Neglected signs shall be considered a public nuisance and are prohibited by this article. Upon written
notification by the building official, such neglected signs shall be removed from the premises and neglected
signs shall be repaired or removed from the premises by the owner, agent or person having beneficial use of the
land, building or structure upon which such sign is located.

(1) The building official shall provide written notification by certified mail to the owner of the sign
regarding the violation. The notification shall state that the offending sign shall be repaired or
removed by the owner, agent or person having beneficial use of the land, building or structure upon
which such sign is located.
(2) The owner of the sign in violation shall be permitted 10 calendar days to respond to the
building official regarding the notification of violation.
(3) Following the 10-day period of response, the owner of the sign in violation shall be notified
that if the sign is not removed or repaired, a citation may be issued and the city may resort to any
civil remedy available to remove or repair the sign, up to and including impoundment. The owner of
the sign in violation shall have 30 days to bring the sign into compliance or remove the sign. If any
sign is determined to present an immediate danger to public health, safety, or welfare, the city shall

Sec. 3.08.016 Nonconforming signs
(a) Definition. A nonconforming sign is a sign and its supporting structure which does not conform to all or
part of the provisions of this article, and was in:
(1) Existence and lawfully erected prior to the effective date of this article;
(2) Existence and lawfully located and used in accordance with the provisions of the prior
ordinance applicable thereto, or which was considered legally nonconforming there under, and has
since been in continuous or regular use; or
(3) Existence, located, and used on the premises at the time it was annexed into the city and has
since been in regular and continuous use.
(b) Any nonconforming sign and its supporting structure, which is destroyed, damaged, dilapidated or
deteriorated, shall not be replaced, repaired, or renovated, in whole or in part, if such replacement, repair or
renovation would require an expenditure of monies in excess of sixty (60) percent of the cost of a new sign,
including its supporting structure, which is substantially the same or similar to the nonconforming sign
destroyed, damaged, dilapidated or deteriorated. Changing an interior panel of a nonconforming sign is
permitted in all cases.
(c) No sign or supporting structure which is lawfully reproduced, repaired, or renovated as a nonconforming
sign shall be increased in area or height.
(d) Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, any sign which is a legally existing nonconforming
sign hereunder may be relocated on the same lot or tract of land, if the sign is required to be removed from its
present location because the property upon which the sign is located is acquired by any governmental agency or
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 166/652
other entity which has or could have acquired the property through the exercise of its power of eminent domain.
Such relocated sign shall be placed, insofar as possible, as to comply with all the provisions of this article.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.22, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.017 Discontinued signs
(a) A sign is considered to be discontinued when the activity that the sign or sign structure advertises ceases to
operate for a period of one year on the premises on which the sign or sign structure is located. If the premises
containing the sign or sign structure is leased, a sign is deemed to be discontinued two years after the activity
ceases to operate on the premises.
(b) An on-premises sign considered to be discontinued may be removed by the owner or the city after
notification has been given of the intent to remove a discontinued sign.
(1) The building official shall provide written notification to the owner of the discontinued sign
regarding the intent to remove the sign. The notification shall state that the discontinued sign shall be
removed by the owner, agent or person having beneficial use of the land, building or structure upon
which such sign is located.
(2) The owner of the discontinued sign shall be permitted 10-calendar days to respond to the
building official regarding removal of the sign. The 10-day period shall be measured from the date of
the postmark of the notification.
(3) Following the 10-day period of response, the owner of the discontinued sign shall be notified
that if the sign is not removed a citation may be issued and the city may resort to any civil remedy
available to remove the sign, up to and including impoundment. The owner of the discontinued sign
shall have 30 days to comply or remove the sign. If any sign is determined to present an immediate
danger to public health, safety, or welfare, the city shall remove it immediately. An extension of the
30-day period may be granted upon demonstration of the sign owner of merit upon the discretion of
the city manager. The city manager may defer such decision to the appellate procedures as defined in
section 3.08.005, at his/her discretion.
(4) Any sign whose use has been deemed discontinued can be legally reoccupied by a new
business or upgraded to a conforming sign by the owner of the sign or owner of the premises at their
expense anytime following the initial notification by complying with the terms of this section.
(5) If the owner of any lot or premises upon which a discontinued sign fails to legally reoccupy,
correct, remedy or remove such sign within one hundred eighty days after the initial notice to do so is
given, the city may do such work as necessary to correct, remedy or remove such condition, or cause
the same to be done, and pay therefor and charge the expenses and appropriate administrative costs
incurred thereby to the owner of such lot. The doing of the work by the city shall not relieve such
person from prosecution for failure to comply with such notice in violation with this regulation.
(6) The city may agree with the owner of the sign or sign structure to remove only a portion of the
sign or sign structure if that action is deemed to be in the interest of the public by the city manager
The city manager may defer such decision to the appellate procedures as defined in section 3.08.005,
at his/her discretion.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.23, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.018 Registration, and removal of nonconforming signs
(a) The owner of a sign that is deemed to be nonconforming with these sign regulations shall be required to
register such nonconformity within 12 months of the effective date of this section.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 167/652
(b) Any nonconforming sign that is not registered after the effective date as noted above shall be required to
comply with the regulations herein and be brought into compliance or be removed.
(c) Compensation to the owner for the relocation, reconstruction, or removal shall be in accordance to the
provisions of chapter 216 of the Local Government Code.
(d) Any nonconforming sign that has not been registered shall be relocated, reconstructed, or removed in
accordance with the process described in section 3.08.013.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.24, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.019 Municipal board of sign control
(a) A municipal board of sign control shall be appointed by the mayor to initiate any action requiring the
relocation, reconstruction, or removal of a sign within the corporate limits of the city or extraterritorial
jurisdiction. The membership of the board shall be comprised of persons as provided by section 216.004 of the
Local Government Code.
(b) The board shall not have authority to consider relief from any of the regulations contained herein but shall
be authorized only to act on matters regarding the relocation, reconstruction, or removal of signs.
(c) Removal of a discontinued sign does not require action from the municipal board of sign control as per
section 216.003(e) of the Local Government Code.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.25, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.020 Special events signage
(a) Special events are generally defined as a festival, fair, tournament, or other similar happening. Should city
staff question a proposed activity or celebration as a valid special event, a description of the proposed activity or
celebration will be prepared by the applicant and forwarded to the administrative staff for consideration of the
event as a special event. Appeal of an administrative staff decision may be pursued by any aggrieved applicant
in accordance with the appellate process defined in section 3.08.005. Business promotions such as grand
openings and sales events shall not be classified as a special event.
(b) Signage associated with a special event shall be erected no earlier than fourteen (14) days prior to the
event and removed no later than forty-eight (48) hours after the event.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.26, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.021 Franchise and special theme signs
Signs that incorporate a theme and identity characteristic with regional and/or national franchises may be
incorporated into the design of the sign upon administrative approval. Height, width, size, and illumination shall
require administrative approval when such elements are in conflict with the regulations contained herein. City
staff may defer administrative approval of any sign request to the appellate process as defined in section
3.08.005. (Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.27, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.022 Sign regulations in planned developments and development agreements
The regulations regarding sign area, sign types, and permitted and prohibited signs may be revised and amended
for specific sites and developments that are located within a planned development or covered by a development
agreement. Where the planned development or development agreement is silent on a sign regulation the
applicable regulation herein shall apply. (Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.28, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.023 Sign coordination plan
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 168/652
(a) A sign coordination plan is required to be prepared for waiver requests. A sign coordination plan is also
required prior to the permitting of specified signs to determine overall sign locations on a property, the
relationship of the signs to surrounding existing, proposed, and future improvements, and to determine
consistency and uniformity among buildings and signs within a unified development zone or residential
development. The sign coordination plan shall be submitted to the city manager. A calendar of official submittal
dates shall be published by the city thirty (30) days prior to the beginning of each calendar year. All applications
received on a date other than an official submittal date shall be dated received on the next official submittal date.
(b) A sign coordination plan shall contain the following information:
(1) Elevations of the signs illustrating the materials of construction, colors, lighting, font of letters,
and dimensions of the signs. If the sign is to be attached to a building, the elevation shall be a
composite of the sign and the building.
(2) Elevations depicting the size of the signs in relation to the size of the buildings within the
development.
(3) A plan drawn to concept plan or site plan specifications, as detailed in the CZO for a planned
development, of the site illustrating the location of existing and proposed signs on the property and, if
required by city staff, on adjacent properties.
(4) Other information to illustrate the consistency and uniformity of the signs.
(5) For unified development signs, the sign coordination plan shall identify a unified development
zone. Only those properties and businesses included within the unified development zone shall be
included on the unified development signs erected within the unified development zone.
(c) For nonresidential and multifamily developments, the sign coordination plan shall be submitted to the city
for review prior to the issuance of a building permit for the property. For single-family and two-family
developments, the sign coordination plan shall be submitted to the city for review with a final plat of the
property.
(d) A sign coordination plan required of specified signs shall be submitted to the city manager. The plan will
be reviewed in accordance with the city's development review schedule and considered for approval by city
staff. Staff may approve or deny a sign coordination plan. Should staff deny a sign coordination plan, the plan
will be forwarded to the municipal court.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.29, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.024 Penalty provision
Any person violating this article, as it exists or may be amended, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and
upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine not to exceed the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00). A
second conviction, including convictions for separate premises, within any sixty-month period shall have a
minimum fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each continuing day's violation under this article shall
constitute a separate offense. The penal provisions imposed under this article shall not preclude the city from
filing suit to enjoin the violation. The city retains all legal rights and remedies available to it pursuant to local,
state and federal law. (Ordinance 08-08-671, sec. 4, adopted 8/25/08)
Secs. 3.08.025–3.08.050 Reserved
Division 2. Permits
Sec. 3.08.051 Permit required to erect or install a sign
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 169/652
(a) Permit required. No sign, other than those exceptions listed in section 3.08.052 of this article, shall be
erected, placed, attached, secured, altered or displayed to the ground, any building, or any structure, until a
permit for such sign has been issued by the building official. Any type of sign not specifically regulated by this
article shall be prohibited, but a permit for such a sign may be sought using the relief procedures set forth in
section 3.08.052. An application for a sign permit may be obtained from the city's building inspection division.
The building official shall approve or deny an application for a sign permit within thirty (30) days of the city's
receipt of the application. A permit will be issued if a proposed sign conforms to all city ordinances. Upon
request by the city, information shall be provided showing the location of all signs on the property and/or
adjacent properties (see section 3.08.022). Incorrect information shall be grounds for revocation of a permit.
(b) To whom issued. No permit for the erection of any sign shall be issued to any person other than those
licensed and bonded in the city in accordance with this article.
(c) Not to issue for prohibited locations. No permit shall be issued under this section for any sign in a district
where signs are prohibited by the city's CZO.
(d) Fees. The fee for sign permits shall be according to the fees established on the city's fee schedule.
(e) Interpretation and administration. The building official shall be responsible for interpreting and
administering this article. The building official may revoke any permit for a sign that is issued in error.
Allegations of errors in orders, decisions, or determinations of the building official in the administration of this
article shall be in accordance with section 3.08.005 of this article, as it exists or may be amended.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.05, adopted 8/25/08)
Sec. 3.08.052 Exemption from permit
The following signs are exempt from these sign regulations unless otherwise provided herein. Exempt signs do
not require the issuance of a sign permit provided the signs comply with the following conditions. Signs that do
not comply with the following conditions are considered as being prohibited.
(1) Flags. Conditions for exemption include:
(A) Consists of the display of flags of federal, state, or local governments.
(B) A flag and its supporting structure shall be located on private property behind the
property line.
(C) Flags may be placed at parks during social and athletic events.
(D) The maximum height of a flagpole shall be forty (40) feet, measured from the surface of
the ground closest to the base of the flagpole.
(E) The maximum area of a flag is sixty (60) square feet.
(F) A maximum of three (3) flags may be located on a property.
(2) Instructional signs. Conditions for exemption include:
(A) The maximum area of an instructional sign is sixteen (16) square feet.
(3) Apartment stake signs. Conditions for exemption include:
(A) An apartment sign is a temporary sign that is used to convey information relating to the
operation of an apartment complex.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 170/652
(B) Apartment signs may be placed in the front yard of a property developed as an apartment
complex no earlier than Friday at 12:00 p.m. and shall be removed from the property no later
than Sunday at 6:00 p.m.
(C) Apartment signs erected internal to a multifamily development and setback a minimum
of 75 feet from a public street shall have no time restriction.
(D) Apartment signs may not be placed in the right-of-way.
(E) Apartment signs erected within the front yard of a property shall not be placed closer than
sixty (60) feet from another apartment sign and shall be placed a minimum of thirty (30) feet
from a side property line.
(F) Apartment signs shall not exceed six (6) square feet in area.
(4) Civic sign. Conditions for exemption include:
(A) A civic sign is a temporary sign that publicizes times or locations of meetings or special
events of homeowners associations, religious organizations or groups, or civic groups. This
definition excludes directional signs for regularly scheduled religious events. A civic sign may
also publicize times or locations of special events for schools and athletic team registrations.
(B) Civic signs shall be erected no more than fourteen (14) days prior to the meeting or event
and removed no more than forty-eight (48) hours after the meeting or event.
(5) Garage sale sign. Conditions for exemption include:
(A) A garage sale sign is a temporary stake sign that advertises a garage sale or yard sale.
(B) A garage sale sign shall not be erected earlier than 12:00 p.m. on the Thursday before the
sale and must be removed by 6:00 p.m. on the Sunday following the sale.
(C) Garage sale signs shall not exceed six (6) square feet in area.
(D) Nonresidents posting a garage sale sign are required to obtain a permit for a ten (10)
dollar deposit to be returned when signs have been removed. Upon failure to remove the signs
by the required deadline the city will remove the signs and the deposit will be forfeited.
(6) Government sign. Conditions for exemption include:
(A) A government sign is a temporary sign used to convey information to the public
regarding city, state, or federal government activities and events.
(7) Home improvement sign. Conditions for exemption include:
(A) A home improvement sign is a temporary sign that displays the name of roofing, fence,
pool, paint, landscape, or other home improvement contractor.
(B) The home improvement sign shall be removed after thirty (30) days of being installed or
when the home improvement work is completed, whichever occurs first.
(C) A home improvement sign shall be erected on the lot on which the home improvement is
occurring. In general, a home improvement sign shall not be erected closer than ten (10) feet
from the edge of the street pavement.
(D) Home improvement signs shall not exceed six (6) square feet in area.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 171/652
(E) A maximum of two (2) home improvement sign shall be erected on a lot.
(8) Open house sign. Conditions for exemption include:
(A) Definition. An open house sign is a temporary sign that advertises the name of the realtor
or owner, date, time, direction to, and/or location of an open house.
(B) An open house sign shall be erected no earlier than one (1) hour prior to the time of open
house and shall be removed no later than one (1) hour after the time of the open house.
(C) Manner. Open house signs shall not exceed six (6) square feet in area.
(9) Residential real estate sign. Conditions for exemption include:
(A) A residential real estate sign is a temporary sign that advertises a home or property for
sale or lease.
(B) Place. A residential real estate sign shall be erected only on the lot on which the home or
property is for sale or lease. In general, a residential real estate sign shall be erected no closer
than ten (10) feet from the street pavement.
(C) Residential real estate signs shall not exceed six (6) square feet in area.
(D) A maximum of one (1) residential real estate sign shall be erected on a lot.
(10) Temporary religious sign. Conditions for exemption include:
(A) A temporary religious sign is a temporary sign that is used to advertise the name of and
provide direction to the location occupied by a religious organization or group that is
temporarily operating in a school or other facility.
(B) A temporary religious sign may be erected during times of worship provided the sign is
placed no earlier than two (2) hours prior to worship and is removed no later than two (2) hours
after worship.
(11) Yard sign. Conditions for exemption include:
(A) A yard sign is a temporary sign that publicizes the arrival of a newborn or the
participation of a family member in a school activity or sport. Yard signs shall also include
signs that advertise the presence of a home security system, animals and seasonal decorations.
(B) Yard signs shall be located only on lots containing an occupied single-family, two-family,
or multifamily dwelling. In general, a yard sign shall be erected no closer than ten (10) feet
from the street pavement.
(C) Signs advertising the presence of a home security system shall not exceed one (1) square
foot in area.
(12) Vehicle signs. Conditions for exemption include:
(A) A vehicular sign is a sign that is attached to or placed in or on a truck, bus, car, trailer,
boat, recreational vehicle, or any other vehicle. Vehicular signs shall exclude bumper stickers,
license plates, and inspection and registration stickers;
(B) Vehicle signs are permitted provided that during periods of inactivity such vehicle is not
parked in the right-of-way or placed in a manner that the sign is readily visible from adjacent
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 172/652
public rights-of-way;
(C) “For Sale” signs placed in or on vehicles when the vehicle is parked or placed in a
manner that the sign is readily visible from adjacent public rights-of-way are prohibited with
the exception that one (1) vehicle containing a “For Sale” sign parked or placed at an occupied
single-family, two-family, townhome, or multifamily dwelling unit is permitted;
(D) The primary purpose of such vehicle is not for display of the sign;
(E) The signs are painted upon or applied directly to an integral part of the vehicle;
(F) The vehicle is in operating condition, currently registered and licensed to operate on
public streets, and actively used in the daily function of the business to which such sign relates;
and
(G) The vehicle is not used primarily as a static display, advertising a product or service, not
utilized as storage, shelter, or distribution points for commercial products or services for the
general public.
(13) Window signs. Conditions for exemption include:
(A) Only one sign with a minimum size of three (3) square foot may be attached to the face
of any window located in the heritage sign overlay district. No handwritten signs are permitted.
(B) Painted signs may take up no more than 50 percent of the total window space.
(14) Governmental and Royse City ISD. Signs required by governmental agencies, including city,
county, state, and Royse City ISD are exempt from the sign regulations contained herein.
(Ordinance 08-08-671, ex. A, sec. 1.06, adopted 8/25/08)
Secs. 3.08.053–3.08.070 Reserved
Division 3. Sign Districts
Sec. 3.08.071 Freeway sign district
The unique character of properties located adjacent to corridors of intense traffic activity such as Interstate
Highway 30 and the DFW Regional Outer Loop encourages regulations that are sensitive to the nature of the
freeway system. It is recognized that signage located along the freeway should be compatible to high speed,
limited access, interstate vehicle traffic.
(1) Limits of the district. The physical limits of the freeway sign district shall be an area parallel to
the freeways. The boundary shall be a width of 300 feet either side of the right-of-way of the
freeway.
(2) Regulation of signs. Signs shall comply with the regulations as provided in table 1.13. In the
event the table is silent as to a specific regulation, the regulation for such sign shall be that which is
provided for the sign in areas located outside the freeway sign district.

Sec. 3.08.072 Heritage sign district
The historic nature of the heritage district requires that signage located within that area be regulated such that the
historic character of the district is protected and enhanced.
(1) Limits of the district. The physical limits of the heritage sign district shall be that area that is
included in the City Main Street District and Heritage Zoning District.
(2) Regulation of signs. Signs shall comply with the regulations as provided in table 1.14.
(3) Illumination limitations. Sign illumination shall be externally lit from the top and shine
downward. No uplighting shall be permitted within the heritage sign district, except that 75 watts or
less are acceptable if necessary for security purposes. Illumination values shall not exceed 5
footcandles. All signs shall be designed, located, shielded and directed so as to prevent the casting of
glare or direct light from artificial illumination upon adjacent publicly dedicated roadway and/or
surrounding property. The lighting must also be substantially contained to the target area.

Sec. 3.08.073 Old town sign district
The historic nature of the old town sign district requires that signage located within that area be regulated such
that the historic character of the district is protected and enhanced.
(1) Limits of the district. The physical limits of the old town sign district shall be that area that is
bounded by Houston Street, Josephine Street, Burton Street, and the northern railroad right-of-way
line.
(2) Regulation of signs. Signs shall comply with the regulations as provided in table 1.15.
(3) Illumination. Sign illumination shall be externally lit from the top and shine downward. No
uplighting shall be permitted within the old town sign district, except that 75 watts or less are
acceptable if necessary for security purposes. Illumination values shall not exceed 5 footcandles. All
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 182/652
signs shall be designed, located, shielded and directed so as to prevent the casting of glare or direct
light from artificial illumination upon adjacent publicly dedicated roadway and/or surrounding
property. The lighting must also be substantially contained to the target area.
