7/3/73)
Secs. 3.11.039–3.11.090 Reserved
Division 3. Street Humps on Residential Roadways
Sec. 3.11.091 Penalty
Any person, firm, corporation or business entity violating this division, as it exists or may be amended, shall be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine not to exceed the sum of
five hundred dollars ($500.00), unless the violation relates to fire safety, zoning or public health and sanitation,
including dumping of refuse, in which [case] the fine shall not exceed the sum of two thousand and no/100
dollars ($2,000.00). Each continuing day's violation under this division shall constitute a separate offense. The
penal provisions imposed under this division shall not preclude the city from filing suit to enjoin the violation.
The city retains all legal rights and remedies available to it pursuant to local, state and federal law. (Ordinance
06-10-533, sec. 3, adopted 10/10/06)
Sec. 3.11.092 Purpose
The city council hereby adopts the following procedures for the consideration of the installation of street humps
on residential roadways. (Ordinance 06-10-533, sec. 2, adopted 10/10/06)
Sec. 3.11.093 Eligible streets
In order to be eligible for installation of street humps, a street shall meet the following minimum requirements:
(1) The street is constructed on a dedicated right-of-way. The city will not install street humps on
private roads or drives.
(2) The street shall be either a concrete street constructed as a type F (residential collector) or type
G (residential) roadway as defined by the city's major thoroughfare plan or an asphalt street
designated as a type F, type G, or not designated on the city's major thoroughfare plan.
(3) The property adjacent to the street shall be either wholly or primarily residential development
or, if undeveloped, shall be either wholly or primarily zoned for residential uses. For purposes of this
division, public parks, public schools, churches, and drainage easements shall be considered
properties zoned for residential uses.
(4) The street shall have no more than one (1) moving lane of traffic in each direction.
(5) The traffic volume on the street shall be less than 5,000 vehicle trips per day.
(6) The street shall have an established speed limit of 30 miles per hour or less.
(7) The street shall not be a primary route for emergency vehicles. The city police and fire
departments shall be consulted prior to the installation of any street hump and shall have the authority
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 201/652
to prohibit installation of street humps on any street considered critical for emergency response.
(8) The city council shall have the sole discretion, except as may be provided in subsection (7)
above, to determine the suitability of any street for the installation of street humps. The determination
of the city council in regard to the suitability of any street for street hump installation, except as
provided in subsection (7) above, shall be final and nonappealable.
(Ordinance 06-10-533, sec. 2.1, adopted 10/10/06)
Sec. 3.11.094 Location on roadway; survey of residents
Once the city council has determined that a roadway is eligible for installation of street humps, the following
conditions shall apply to installation of the street humps:
(1) Sight distance. Adequate sight distance must exist at the desired location of the street hump to
safely accommodate traffic operations after installation of the street hump.
(2) Survey of adjacent residents. A street hump shall not be located in front of, or immediately
adjacent to, any property if the owner of that property objects to its placement, or, in the case of a
property containing multiple low density dwellings, if the majority of the residents upon such
property object to its placement. In order to determine resident support for any proposed installation
of street humps, a survey of area residents meeting the requirements of this section shall be reviewed
by the transportation department. The city shall make available a survey form to any interested
person for use in collecting signatures from the survey area. The survey form shall include a brief
description of the request, traffic operation considerations, and instructions to those completing the
form. In order to be considered for review by the transportation department, the survey shall meet the
following requirements:
(A) For purposes of this division, “survey area” shall include all residences within 500 feet of
the proposed location of the street hump. If the 500-foot distance extends into any part of an
adjacent block, the entire length of the adjacent block shall also be included. For purposes of
this division, “block” shall mean a row of adjacent residences upon a street or roadway which
are separated from other residences upon the street or roadway by an intersecting street or
roadway. Only single-family, duplex, triplex or fourplex residences shall be included in the
survey response. Townhomes shall be considered single-family residences for purposes of this
division. All residences (as described above) whose front or side yard adjoins the street on
which the street hump request is being presented shall be included. Residences which have only
a rear yard adjacent to the street on which the street hump request is being presented shall not
be included. Only one (1) resident per residential address may sign the form. The form shall
include the street address, printed name, signature, and preference (denominated as “support,”
“oppose,” or “no preference”) for each person signing the survey.
(B) A person making request for a street hump and requesting the survey form from the city
shall have three (3) months to secure signatures and submit the form to the transportation
department for consideration. If the necessary signatures are not obtained within that time, a
new survey form will have to be initiated.
(C) In order to be considered for installation of a street hump, at least eighty percent (80%) of
the residents in the survey area must complete the survey form and indicate support for the
installation of the street hump. Only the “support” responses will be considered in determining
the required support level. “Oppose” and “no preference” responses shall not be considered.
The city director of public works shall review the submitted survey to verify that the required
survey area was included and to determine if the 80% threshold of support was achieved.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 202/652
(3) Administrative fee. When a requestor has obtained the requisite number of “support” signatures
(within the time frame set forth herein) the survey form shall be returned to the transportation
department and the requestor shall pay the administrative fee established by the city for processing
such requests.
(Ordinance 06-10-533, sec. 2.2, adopted 10/10/06)
Sec. 3.11.095 Installation procedure; payment of installation cost
(a) When a submitted survey form has been verified as meeting the required survey area support level, the
transportation department shall place the street on a list of streets approved for street hump installation and shall
mail a letter to residents in the survey area advising of the approved street hump request. The letter shall also
advise that the installation cost shall be borne by the residents of the survey area, and that payment of the
installation cost must be made to the city in full before installation of the street hump, and advise of the name
and telephone number of the survey area representative.
(b) The city shall submit an invoice to the survey area representative for the cost of the street hump
installation. The survey area representative will bear the responsibility of collecting and submitting payment for
the street humps to the city. Upon receipt of payment in full of the installation cost of the street hump(s), the city
will schedule installation of the street hump(s) in accordance with the transportation department's normal
scheduling process.
(c) The transportation department shall establish the cost for each street hump installation, and such cost will
be based on the actual cost for a typical street hump installation, including any necessary pavement markings
and/or signage.
(d) If full payment of the cost of the street hump installation has not been made within one (1) year of the date
of the invoice, the street will be removed from the list of streets approved for street hump installation and it will
then be necessary for the survey process described in this division to be reinitiated for consideration of any street
hump upon such roadway.
(Ordinance 06-10-533, sec. 2.3, adopted 10/10/06)
Sec. 3.11.096 Appeals and variances
The city council shall serve as an appeal committee and may consider requests for unusual conditions that do not
fall within the guidelines set forth in this division or for other locations that do not strictly meet the criteria set
forth herein. The following procedure shall govern requests for appeals and variances:
(1) Requests for variances or appeals shall be submitted to the director of public works or his or
her designee and shall describe with particularity the reason(s) why an appeal or variance is being
requested.
(2) If the director of public works, or his or her designee, is unable to resolve the issue giving rise
to the request for variance or appeal, the request shall be forwarded to the city council for
determination. If a majority of the city council determines to consider the request for variance or
appeal, it will be scheduled for a future meeting. If a majority of the city council determines not to
consider the request for variance or appeal at a future meeting, the person making the request shall be
notified of the city council's determination not to consider the request for variance or appeal. If the
request is scheduled for a future meeting, residents may appear at the meeting and, subject to the
discretion of the city council, may be permitted to speak in support of or opposition to the request for
variance or appeal. All determinations of the city council are final and nonappealable. All appeals or
requests for variance which the city council determines, in its sole discretion, to consider, shall be
scheduled on a regular agenda for a city council meeting. No appeal or request for variance will be
considered or discussed unless it has first been placed on a city council agenda for consideration.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 203/652
(Ordinance 06-10-533, sec. 2.4, adopted 10/10/06)
Sec. 3.11.097 Removal or alteration
The procedure for removal of street humps, unless the city has determined to remove any street hump for
purposes of public health, safety or welfare, shall be the same as for the installation of street humps and shall
require the support of at least 80% of residents in the survey area for removal or alteration of the street hump.
The cost of removal or alteration of the street hump shall be borne by the residents of the survey area, and
payment therefor shall be made in the manner set forth herein for installation of street humps. (Ordinance 06-10-
533, sec. 2.5, adopted 10/10/06)
Sec. 3.11.098 Design standards
The transportation department shall maintain design standards for street humps, which shall govern the
installation of street humps within the city as provided in this division. (Ordinance 06-10-533, sec. 2.6, adopted
10/10/06)
Sec. 3.11.099 Review of regulations
The city council shall review the street hump policy and this division on a no less frequent basis than once every
two (2) years, with the first review being performed no more than one (1) year after installation of the first street
hump installed in accordance with the procedures set forth in this division. (Ordinance 06-10-533, sec. 2.7,
adopted 10/10/06)
Secs. 3.11.100–3.11.130 Reserved
Division 4. Construction of Facilities in Right-of-Way*
Sec. 3.11.131 Purpose
The city council hereby declares its purpose in enacting this division is to protect the health, safety and welfare
of the public in connection with the use of the city streets. (Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 2, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.132 Definitions
Agency. Any person (including a franchised or licensed person) or certified telecommunications provider.
“Agency” includes all contractors and subcontractors hired or retained to do construction for an agency.
Certified telecommunications provider (CTP). A person who has been issued a certificate of convenience and
necessity, certificate of operating authority, or service provider certificate of operating authority by the public
utility commission to offer local exchange telephone service.
Director. The director of public works for the city or his/her designee.
Facilities. Any and all of the wires, cables, fibers, duct spaces, manholes, poles, conduits, underground and
overhead passageways and other equipment, structures, plant and appurtenances and all associated physical
equipment placed in, on or under the public right-of-way.
Person. Any entity, whether a natural person, partnership, corporation of any type, joint venture, or any other
legal entity.
Public infrastructure contractor. A person hired or retained to do construction for facilities that will be
maintained by the city. “Public infrastructure contractor” includes all subcontractors.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 204/652
Street, public (or public way, public right-of-way, or right-of-way). The area on, below, or above a public
roadway, highway, street, public sidewalk, alley, waterway, or utility easement in which the municipality has an
interest. The term does not include the airwaves above a right-of-way with regard to wireless
telecommunications.
(Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 3, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.133 Penalty
Any person, firm, corporation or business entity violating this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor,
and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine not to exceed the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00),
unless the violation relates to fire safety or public health and sanitation, including dumping of refuse, in which
[case] the fine shall not exceed the sum of two thousand and no/100 dollars ($2,000.00). Each continuing day's
violation under this article shall constitute a separate offense. The penal provisions imposed under this article
shall not preclude the city from filing suit to enjoin the violation. The city retains all legal rights and remedies
available to it pursuant to local, state and federal law. (Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 20, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.134 Violations
It shall be unlawful for any agency or public infrastructure contractor to commence or continue construction,
installation or operation of facilities within the right-of-way in the city except as provided by the ordinances of
the city and the directives of the public works department. All construction activity in any city right-of-way will
be in accordance with applicable law. (Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 4, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.135 Conflicts with existing franchises
If any provision of this article conflicts with an existing franchise agreement, the franchise agreement shall
prevail until the expiration thereof. (Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 22, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.136 Registration of agencies and contractors; construction permits
(a) Registration.
(1) In order to protect the public health, safety and welfare, all agencies and public infrastructure
contractors placing facilities or engaging in construction, excavation, encroachments, and work
activities within or upon any public right-of-way must register with the city. Registration must be
renewed annually. If a registration is not renewed, construction permits will not be issued to the
agency or public infrastructure contractor by the city, and the penalty provisions contained herein
shall apply. When any information provided by the applicant for the registration changes, the agency
shall notify the city of the change no more than thirty (30) days after the date the change is made.
Registration shall include:
(A) The name of the agency that is the owner of the facilities to be located in the public rightof-
way. In the case of a public infrastructure contractor, the name of the public infrastructure
contractor and the name of the developer for whom the public infrastructure contractor is
working.
(B) The name(s), address(es) and telephone number(s) of the person(s) who will be the
contact person(s) for the agency.
(C) The name(s), address(es) and telephone number(s) of any contractor(s) or
subcontractor(s), if known, who will be working in the public rights-of-way on behalf of the
agency or public infrastructure contractor.
(D) The name and telephone number(s) of an emergency contact for the agency or public
infrastructure contractor who shall be available twenty-four (24) hours a day.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 205/652
(E) The name(s), address(es) and telephone number(s) of the person(s) who will be receiving
plans of city construction projects on behalf of the agency or public infrastructure.
(F) Proof of insurance as required by this section.
(G) A city street map marked in such a manner as to evidence on which streets the agency or
public infrastructure contractor has placed facilities (not including boxes and other
appurtenances) along thoroughfares, updated annually.
(2) Registration shall be a prerequisite to issuance of a construction permit. Each agency or public
infrastructure contractor shall update and keep current its registration with the city at all times.
(3) Notwithstanding any other provision in this division, the city shall not request any information
that is customer-specific, or as to the facilities' specific electronic configuration, capacity, or fiber
count. However, to the extent the agency or public infrastructure contractor deems information
requested by the city to be proprietary or confidential, the agency or public infrastructure contractor
must notify the city by a conspicuous written notation of the proprietary and/or confidential nature of
any information, reports, documents, or writings as they are provided to the city. The city agrees to
maintain the confidentiality of the information, reports, documents, and writings to the extent
permitted by law. Upon receipt by the city of any third-party request for any such confidential
information, reports, documents, or writings submitted by the agency or public infrastructure
contractor that has such a notation, the city shall notify the agency or public infrastructure contractor
as promptly as circumstances allow of the request in writing (by facsimile transmission if such fax
number is provided). To the extent allowed by law, the city shall request an attorney general's opinion
before disclosing any such confidential information, reports, documents, or writings.
(b) Construction permit.
(1) Required; exceptions. No agency or public infrastructure contractor shall perform any
construction or installation of facilities in the right-of-way without first obtaining a construction
permit, except as provided herein. The permit will be in the name of the agency or public
infrastructure contractor who will own the facilities constructed. The application for a permit must be
completed and signed by a representative of the owner of the facilities to be constructed.
(A) Permits issued under emergency conditions. Any agency or public infrastructure
contractor maintaining facilities in the public rights-of-way may proceed with repairs upon
existing facilities without a permit when emergency circumstances demand that the work be
done immediately. The agency or public infrastructure contractor doing the work shall notify
the city police department, by telephone, as soon as possible, of the agency's or public
infrastructure contractor's need to perform emergency work, and the public works department
no later than the next business day, by telephone, fax, or e-mail, when an emergency permit is
required. A permit application must be submitted no later than the next business day after the
work is commenced.
(B) The phrase “construction or installation of facilities” or “construction and/or installation
work” includes repair or maintenance of existing facilities, save and except the installation of
facilities necessary to initiate service to a customer's property, or repair or maintenance of
existing facilities, unless such repair or maintenance requires:
(i) Breaking of pavement;
(ii) The closure of a nonresidential traffic lane before 9:00 a.m. and/or after 6:00 p.m.;
(iii) Excavation; and/or
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 206/652
(iv) Boring.
(2) Contents. The permit shall state to whom it is issued, location of work, location of facilities,
dates and times work is to take place and any other conditions set out by the director of public works
or his/her designee.
(3) Application requirements; submission of plans. The application for a permit will provide the
director with documentation in the format specified by the public works department describing:
(A) The proposed location and route of all facilities to be constructed or installed and the
applicant's plan for right-of-way construction.
(B) Engineering plans, which will be on a reasonable scale, or provide sufficient information,
acceptable to the public works department.
(C) Details of the location of all right-of-way that the applicant and/or owner plans to use.
(D) Description of all existing city utilities in relation to the applicant's proposed route.
(E) Description of what the applicant proposes to install.
(F) Detail of plans to remove and replace asphalt and/or concrete in streets, driveways,
alleys, and sidewalks.
(G) Drawing of any bores, trenches, handholds, manholes, switch great [gears,]
transformation [transformers], pedestals, etc. (including approximate depth) located in the
public right-of-way.
(H) Typical details of manholes and/or handholds the applicant plans to use or access.
(I) Complete legend of drawings submitted by the applicant, which may be provided by
reference to previously submitted documents.
(J) One (1) set of plans must be submitted with the permit application.
(K) The construction and installation methods to be employed for the protection of existing
structures, fixtures, and facilities within or adjacent to the right-of-way, and the estimated dates
and times work will occur, all of which (methods, dates, times, etc.) are subject to approval of
the director.
(L) Proof of insurance or net worth as required herein.
(M) If traffic is to be obstructed, a traffic-control plan.
(N) The name(s), address(es) and telephone number(s) of any contractor(s) or
subcontractor(s) who will be working in the public rights-of-way on behalf of the agency or
public infrastructure contractor.
(4) Compliance with permit. All construction and installation in the right-of-way shall be in
accordance with the permit for the facilities. After permit issuance, the director shall be provided
access to the work and to such further information as the director may reasonably require to ensure
compliance with the permit.
(5) Copy of permit and plans to be maintained at site. A copy of the construction permit and
approved engineering plans shall be maintained at the construction site and made available for
inspection by the director at all times when construction or installation work is occurring.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 207/652
(6) Time limit for completing work. All construction or installation work authorized by permit
must be completed in the time specified in the construction permit. If the work cannot be completed
in the specified time periods, the permittee may request an extension from the director. If the request
for an extension is made prior to the expiration of the permit, all work authorized by the permit may
proceed while the extension request is pending, but must cease immediately upon a denial of the
extension request.
(7) Insurance and bonds.
(A) An applicant must provide a certificate of insurance in the amount of five million dollars
($5,000,000.00) per occurrence, ten million dollars ($10,000,000.00) aggregate, or other
amount if approved by the director of public works. Such requirements may be waived by the
director if the applicant provides acceptable evidence of self-insurance.
(B) The coverage must be on an “occurrence” basis and must include coverage for personal
injury, contractual liability, premises liability, medical damages, underground, explosion and
collapse hazards, actions of independent contractors, completed operations to be maintained for
one (1) year, business automobile liability (including coverage for any owned, hired or nonowned
motor vehicles and automobile contractual liability), and statutory workers'
compensation benefits as required by the state, or other laws as required by labor union
agreements, including employer's liability coverage.
(C) Each certificate must include a cancellation provision in which the insurance company is
required to notify the city in writing not fewer than thirty (30) days before canceling, failing to
renew, or reducing policy limits.
(D) The applicant shall file the required original certificates of insurance with the application
for a construction permit. The certificate shall state the policy number; the name of the
insurance company; the name and address of the agent or authorized representative of the
insurance company; the name, address and telephone number of the insured; the policy
expiration date; and specific coverage amounts. The insurance company must be licensed to do
business in the state.
(E) The above requirements may be met by utilities with a current franchise, license or other
municipal authorization, and applicants governed by chapter 283 of the Local Government
Code, if the current franchise, license or municipal authorization adequately provides for
insurance in favor of the city.
(F) An applicant satisfies the requirements of this section, including insurance requirements,
if it files with the city a certificate of self-insurance issued by the state, or a letter written by the
applicant in those instances where a state certificate is not issued, which provides the same
coverage as required herein. The applicant must demonstrate by written information that it has
adequate financial resources to be a self-insured entity as reasonably determined by the city.
(8) Submission of request for permit. A request for a permit must be submitted at least two (2)
working days before the proposed commencement of work, unless waived by the director.
(9) Action on request for permit. Requests for permits will be acted on by the director promptly
after receiving all the information specified herein. The director will use his/her best efforts to act on
a request for permit as soon as possible.
(10) Preconstruction meeting. A preconstruction meeting shall be conducted among the director,
the permittee and the construction contractor.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 208/652
(c) Franchise requirements. A registration or a construction permit shall not constitute a franchise, and shall
not replace any obligations to either obtain a franchise, if applicable, or to pay a fee pursuant to a franchise
obligation.
(d) New developments. In the city, the physical construction of public infrastructure in new developments is
the responsibility of the developer of the land. Ownership of that infrastructure remains with the developer of the
land until accepted by the city. Any agency or public infrastructure contractor performing work on infrastructure
which is within a public right-of-way, but prior to acceptance by the city, shall obtain a permit from the city and
permission from the owner of the infrastructure in the public right-of-way. The agency shall be financially
responsible to the owner of the infrastructure to carry out all remedial work necessary to receive acceptance by
the city of that infrastructure. This financial obligation shall apply only to the work in the public right-of-way
done by the agency or public infrastructure contractor. The city will not accept for dedication public rights-ofway,
or other property, where work performed is not in accordance with applicable city specifications.
(e) Denial of permit.
(1) A permit may be denied for any one (1) of the following reasons:
(A) Not having liability insurance for the required amount as required herein.
(B) Consistently failing to perform in accordance with the requirements of this division.
(C) Requesting to cut a city-maintained street that can be crossed by jacking, boring or
tunneling.
(D) Proposing barricading, channelizing, signing, warning or other traffic-control procedures
or equipment that do not comply with the requirements of the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic
Control Devices.
(E) The activity or the manner in which the construction or installation work is to be
performed will violate a city ordinance or a state statute.
(F) Failure to furnish all of the information required by this division or, except for good cause
shown, to file the applications within the time prescribed by this division.
(G) Misrepresenting or falsifying any information in the applications.
(H) Failing to comply with the performance warranty/guarantee as provided in this division.
(I) Having outstanding debts to the city.
(J) Lack of available space.
(K) The proposed activity will substantially interfere with vehicular or pedestrian traffic, and
no procedures, or procedures which are inconsistent [consistent] with this division have been
implemented to minimize the interference.
(2) An agency or public infrastructure contractor may appeal a permit denial in accordance with
the provisions herein.
(f) Suspension or revocation of permit.
(1) The city may suspend or revoke by stop work order any or all permits granted to allow work in
the public rights-of-way for the following reasons and subject to the procedural guidelines noted in
this division and any agreement that applies to the agency or public infrastructure contractor using
the public rights-of-way, as well as any limitations imposed by federal or state law:
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 209/652
(A) Failing to comply with an order of the director, city engineer or his/her designee(s);
(B) The recognition that a permit was issued in error;
(C) Failing to comply with restrictions or requirements placed on the permit by the city
engineer or his/her designee(s); or
(D) Violating any provision of this division.
(2) An agency or public infrastructure contractor may appeal a permit suspension in accordance
with the provisions of subsection (g) of this section.
(3) The city engineer may reinstate a previously suspended permit when the conditions that caused
such permit to be suspended are remedied by the agency or public infrastructure contractor to the
satisfaction of the director or city engineer.
(g) Appeals.
(1) Applicability. Appeals may be filed pursuant to this section for decisions of the director or city
engineer or his designee(s) and for the denial, suspension, or revocation of a permit. However, the
appeal process provided by this section shall not be available for criminal violations of this division.
(2) Appeal to city manager. A permittee may appeal decisions made by the director or city
engineer or his designee pursuant to this division by filing a written appeal with the city manager
within five (5) business days of receipt of denial, suspension, or revocation of the permit. An appeal
filed pursuant to this section shall specifically state the basis for the aggrieved party's challenge to the
city's authority under this division.
(3) Issuance of decision by city manager. Decisions of the city manager shall be issued within
seven (7) working days of receipt of the written appeal.
(4) Appeal to city council. A permittee may appeal a decision of the city manager to the city
council by filing a written appeal within five (5) business days of the date of the city manager's
decision. If reasonably possible, and to the extent allowed by law, an appeal to the city council will
be placed on the city council's next regularly scheduled meeting for determination. A decision made
by the city council is final.
(Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 5, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.137 Construction standards
(a) Notification of commencement of construction. The director must be notified twenty-four (24) hours in
advance that construction is ready to proceed by either the right-of-way user or their contractor or representative.
The notice must include the name, address and phone number of the contractor who will perform the actual
construction, including the name and telephone number of an individual with the contractor who will be
available at all times during construction.
(b) Compliance with applicable regulations. All construction shall be in conformance with all city codes and
applicable local, state and federal laws.
(c) Posting of information. A three-foot information sign stating the identity of the person doing the work, the
telephone number and the permittee's identity and telephone number shall be placed at the location where
construction is to occur twenty-four (24) hours prior to the beginning of work in the right-of-way and shall
continue to be posted at the location during the entire time the work is occurring.
(d) Erosion control and stormwater management.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 210/652
(1) Erosion control measures, as applicable, and advance warning signs, markers, cones and
barricades must be in place before work begins.
(2) The director may require the permittee to show proof of EPA-approved plans relating to
stormwater and erosion when applicable or a letter stating they are not required to obtain such
approval.
(3) The permittee shall be responsible for stormwater management erosion control that complies
with city, state and federal guidelines.
(e) Lane closures and traffic control. Lane closures on major thoroughfares will be limited to between 8:30
a.m. and 3:00 p.m. unless the director grants prior written approval. Barricades and signage shall be installed in
accordance with the Texas Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices. Traffic control shall be done in
compliance with section 3.11.138.
(f) Responsibility of permittee. Without affecting the legal relationship between the permittee and its
contractors, permittees are responsible for the workmanship and any damages by its contractors. A responsible
representative of the permittee will be available to the city's public works department at all times during
construction.
(g) Notification of damage to utilities. The permittee or its contractor or subcontractor will notify the city's
public works department and the affected utility immediately of any damage to other utilities, either city or
privately owned.
(h) Requirements for street cuts and repairs. Except in the case of an emergency, which is governed by section
3.11.136(b)(1)(A) of this article, when a street or sidewalk cut is required, the permittee must obtain prior
written approval and all requirements of the city's public works department shall be followed. Repair of all street
and sidewalk removals must be made promptly to avoid safety hazards to vehicle and pedestrian traffic.
(1) When emergency repairs are deemed necessary by the city engineer to correct a situation that is
hazardous to the public, the agency or public infrastructure contractor that is responsible for the cut
shall be notified immediately. If the agency or public infrastructure contractor does not provide an
acceptable schedule for making the emergency repair within six (6) hours of being notified, the
repairs may be performed by the city, and the agency or public infrastructure contractor will be billed
for the actual cost of the work necessary to complete the project, which shall include, but not be
limited to, the costs of removing city employees and/or workers from other projects and cleanup.
(2) The agency or public infrastructure contractor will be required to maintain the interim cut
repair until they have completed final repairs. Traffic-bearing steel plates shall be utilized on all
concrete paving cuts until required curing is accomplished. Asphalt shall be used to provide smooth
ramps at the edges. Plates or asphalt may be used for temporary repairs.
(i) Covering of holes. All bore pits, potholes, trenches or other holes shall be filled in or covered daily, unless
other safety requirements are approved by the city's public works department.
(j) Interference with city utilities. Newly installed facilities must not interfere with city utilities, especially
gravity-dependent facilities.
(k) Depth of underground utilities. Underground or buried utilities must be installed at a minimum depth as
determined by industry standard, unless agreed to otherwise by the city and the permittee.
(l) Directional boring. All directional boring will have the locator place bore marks and depths while boring is
in progress. The locator shall place a mark at each stem with a paint dot and depth at least every other stem.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 211/652
(m) Working hours. Except in an emergency or as provided in subsection (e) of this section, the normal
working hours for permitted activities in the rights-of-way are 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday.
Permitted work that needs to be performed after 6:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday must be approved in
writing by the director in advance. Any permitted work performed outside the above work hours must be
approved, in writing, twenty-four (24) hours in advance by the director.
(n) Responsibility for obtaining line locates. The permittee or its contractor or subcontractor working in the
right-of-way is responsible for obtaining line locates from all affected utilities prior to any excavation.
(o) Verification of location of affected facilities. The contractor will be responsible for physically verifying the
location, both horizontal and vertical, of all affected facilities prior to any boring.
(p) Interference with rights of public or existing improvements. Work in the public rights-of-way, on other
public property, near public property, or on or near private property shall be done in a manner that causes the
least interference with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners and residents. The agency's or
public infrastructure contractor's facilities shall be constructed or maintained in such a manner as not to interfere
with sewers, water pipes, or any other property of the city, or with any other pipes, wires, conduits, pedestals,
structures, or other facilities that may have been laid in the rights-of-way by or under the city's authority. The
agency's or public infrastructure contractor's facilities shall be located, erected, and maintained so as not to
endanger or interfere with the lives of persons, or to interfere with existing improvements or to unnecessarily
hinder or obstruct the free use of the rights-of-way or other public property, and shall comply with section
3.11.138 and the traffic-control plan submitted as part of the construction permit application.
(q) English-speaking representative required; identification on vehicles. Agencies and public infrastructure
contractors subject to this division must have a minimum of one English-speaking representative at the site
where work is being performed at all times. Additionally, each of the agency's or public infrastructure
contractor's vehicles shall bear a sign identifying the agency or public infrastructure contractor that owns the
vehicles.
(Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 6, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.138 Traffic control
(a) It shall be the responsibility of the agency or public infrastructure contractor to notify and coordinate all
work in the public rights-of-way with the city's public works department.
(b) When it is necessary to obstruct traffic, a traffic-control plan shall be submitted to the city prior to starting
construction. No permit will be issued until the plan is approved by the city. No agency or public infrastructure
contractor shall block access to and from private property, or block emergency vehicles, or block access to fire
hydrants, fire stations, fire escapes, water valves, underground vaults, valve housing structures, or any other vital
equipment, unless the agency or public infrastructure contractor provides the city with written verification of
written notice delivered to the owner or occupant of the facility, equipment, or property at least 48 hours in
advance.
(c) When necessary for public safety, the agency or public infrastructure contractor shall employ flagpersons
whose duties shall be to control traffic around or through the construction site. The use of flagpersons may be
required by the city engineer.
(d) Traffic-control devices and barricades, as defined in the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control
Devices, must be used whenever it is necessary to close a traffic lane or sidewalk. Traffic-control devices and
barricades are to be supplied by the agency or public infrastructure contractor. If used at night, they must be
reflectorized and must be illuminated or have barricade warning lights.
(e) The Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices or any successor publication thereto shall be used
as a guide for all maintenance and construction signing. The agency or public infrastructure contractor shall
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 212/652
illustrate on the permit the warning and control devices proposed for use. At the direction of the director or city
engineer, such warning and control devices shall be modified.
(f) The city engineer may refuse to issue a permit if proposed construction activity will substantially interfere
with vehicular traffic flow on major thoroughfares or is inconsistent with procedures of this division.
(Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 8, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.139 Minimizing impacts of work
(a) Noise, dust and debris. Each agency and public infrastructure contractor shall conduct work in such a
manner as to avoid unnecessary inconvenience and annoyance to the general public and occupants of
neighboring property. In the performance of the work, the agency or public infrastructure contractor shall take
appropriate measures to reduce noise, dust, and unsightly debris.
(b) Trash and construction materials.
(1) Each agency and public infrastructure contractor shall maintain the work site so that:
(A) Trash and construction materials are contained so that they are not blown off of the
construction site.
(B) Trash is removed from a construction site often enough so that it does not become a
health, fire, or safety hazard.
(C) Trash dumpsters and storage or construction trailers are not placed in the street without
specific approval of the city engineer.
(2) The agency or public infrastructure contractor may only use approved trash haulers when
working in the public rights-of-way.
(c) Deposit of dirt and other material on roadways. Each agency and public infrastructure contractor shall
eliminate the tracking of mud or debris upon any street or sidewalk. Equipment and trucks used during
construction, excavation, or work activity shall be cleaned of mud and debris prior to leaving any work site.
(d) Protection of trees and landscaping. Each agency and public infrastructure contractor shall protect trees,
landscape, and landscape features as required by the city and shall be responsible for supplemental maintenance
and watering. All protective measures shall be provided at the expense of the agency or public infrastructure
contractor.
(e) Protection of paved surfaces from equipment damage. Backhoe equipment outriggers shall be fitted with
rubber pads whenever outriggers are placed on any paved surface. Tracked vehicles with grousers are not
permitted on paved surfaces unless specific precautions are taken to protect the surface. The agency or public
infrastructure contractor shall be responsible for any damage caused to the pavement by the operation of such
equipment and shall repair such surfaces. Failure to do so will result in the use of the agency's or public
infrastructure contractor's performance warranty/guarantee by the city to repair any damage, and possibly the
requirement of additional warranty(ies)/guarantee(s).
(f) Protection of property. Each agency and public infrastructure contractor shall protect from injury any
public rights-of-way and adjoining property by providing adequate support and taking other necessary measures.
The agency or public infrastructure contractor shall, at its own expense, shore up and protect all buildings, walls,
fences, or other property likely to be damaged during the work and shall be responsible for all damage to public
or private property resulting from failure to properly protect and carry out work in the public rights-of-way.
(g) Cleanup. As the work progresses, all public rights-of-way and private property shall be thoroughly cleaned
of all rubbish, excess dirt, rock, and other debris. All cleanup operations shall be done at the expense of the
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 213/652
agency or public infrastructure contractor. The agency or public infrastructure contractor shall restore any
disturbed area to its original condition.
(h) Vehicle parking. Each agency and public infrastructure contractor shall make provisions for employee and
construction vehicle parking so that neighborhood parking adjacent to a work site is not impacted.
(i) Walkways. Each agency and public infrastructure contractor shall maintain an adequate and safe
unobstructed walkway around a construction site.
(Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 9, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.140 Submission of as-built plans
(a) Right-of-way users will provide the director with as-built plans within ninety (90) days of completion of
facilities in the right-of-way. The plans shall be provided to the city in a format used in the ordinary course of
the user's business to the extent they are prepared in the ordinary course of business.
(b) The director may, for good cause, waive all or portions of this requirement. The determination of good
cause shall include, but is not limited to, assessment of:
(1) The right-of-way user's ability to feasibly and economically remove customer-specific,
proprietary or confidential information from its plans; and
(2) The right-of-way user's standard business practice relative to the preparation of construction
and as-built plans.
The director may reassess waivers from time to time to determine whether a right-of-way user's ability to
provide as-built plans has changed.
(Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 10, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.141 Performance warranty
(a) Any warranty made hereunder shall serve as security for the performance of work necessary to repair the
public rights-of-way if the agency or public infrastructure contractor fails to make the necessary repairs or to
complete the work under the permit.
(b) The agency or public infrastructure contractor, by acceptance of the permit, expressly warrants and
guarantees complete performance of the work in a manner acceptable to the city and warrants and guarantees all
work done for a period of one (1) year after the date of acceptance (acceptance subject to the terms set forth
herein) and agrees to maintain upon demand and to make all necessary repairs during the one-year period. This
warranty shall include all repairs and actions needed as a result of:
(1) Defects in workmanship;
(2) Settling of fills or excavations;
(3) Any unauthorized deviations from the approved plans and specifications;
(4) Failure to barricade;
(5) Failure to clean up during and after performance of the work;
(6) Restoration of improvements, including, but not limited to, landscaping and irrigation; and
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 214/652
(7) Any other violation of this division or the ordinances of the city which cause the right-of-way
to not be in a condition equal to or better than it was in prior to work performed in accordance with a
construction permit.
(c) The one-year warranty period shall run from the date of the city's acceptance (acceptance subject to the
terms set forth herein) of the work, which shall be the date of the letter of acceptance issued by the city to the
agency or public infrastructure contractor. If repairs are required during the one-year warranty period, those
repairs need only be warranted until the end of the initial one-year period starting with the date of probationary
acceptance. It is not necessary that a new one-year warranty be provided for subsequent repairs after
probationary acceptance.
(d) At any time prior to completion of the one-year warranty period, the city may notify the agency or public
infrastructure contractor of any needed repairs. Such repairs shall be completed within twenty-four (24) hours if
the defects are determined by the city to be an imminent danger to the public health, safety, and welfare.
Nonemergency repairs shall be completed within thirty (30) calendar days after notice.
(Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 11, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.142 Indemnification
To the extent authorized by law, each agency or public infrastructure contractor placing facilities in the public
rights-of-way shall agree to, promptly defend, indemnify, and hold the city, its officers, agents and employees
harmless from and against all damages, costs, losses, or expenses for the repair, replacement or restoration of
city's property, equipment, materials, structures, and facilities that are damaged, destroyed, or found to be
defective as a result of the agency's or public infrastructure contractor's acts or omissions; and from and against
any and all claims, demands, suits, causes of action, and judgments for damage to or loss of the property of any
agency or public infrastructure contractor (including, but not limited to, any person, its agents, officers,
employees, and subcontractors, the city's agents, officers, and employees, and third parties), and/or death, bodily
injury, illness, disease, loss of services, or loss of income or wages to any person (including, but not limited to,
the agents, officers, and employees of the person, the person's subcontractors and the city, and third parties),
arising out of, incident to, concerning, or resulting from the negligent or willful act or omissions of the agency or
public infrastructure contractor, or its agents, employees, and/or subcontractors, in the performance of activities
pursuant to this division. (Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 12, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.143 Alteration of facilities due to public works projects; tree trimming
(a) Whenever by reason of widening or straightening of streets, water or sewer line projects, or any other
public works projects, it shall be deemed necessary by the governing body of the city to remove, alter, change,
adapt, or conform the underground or overhead facilities of a right-of-way user, such alteration shall be made by
the owner of the facilities at their expense, unless otherwise provided for by state law or a current franchise,
within 120 days from receipt of notice to make the alterations, unless a different schedule has been approved by
the director.
(b) An owner may trim trees in or over the public rights-of-way for the safe and reliable operation, use and
maintenance of its facilities. All tree trimming shall be performed in accordance with standards promulgated by
the National Arborist Association and the International Society of Arboriculture. All tree trimmings shall be
removed from the public right-of-way daily.
(Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 13, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.144 Improperly installed facilities
(a) Any person doing work in the city right-of-way shall properly install, repair, upgrade and maintain
facilities.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 215/652
(b) Facilities installed after the effective date of this division shall be considered to be improperly installed,
repaired, upgraded or maintained if:
(1) The installation, repairs, upgrade or maintenance endangers people;
(2) The facilities do not meet applicable federal, state or city codes;
(3) The facilities are not capable of being located using standard practices; or
(4) The facilities are not located in the proper place in accordance with the directions provided by
the city's public works department.
(Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 14, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.145 Restoration of property
(a) Users of the right-of-way shall restore property affected by construction of facilities to a condition that is
equal to or better than the condition of the property prior to the performance of the work.
(b) Restoration must be to the reasonable satisfaction of the city's public works department. The restoration
shall include, but not be limited to:
(1) Replacing all ground cover with ground cover that is the same or better than the type of ground
cover impacted during work by sodding;
(2) Installation of all manholes and handholds, as required;
(3) Backfilling all bore pits, potholes, trenches or any other holes within seven (7) days of
excavation, unless other safety requirements are approved by the director of public works;
(4) Leveling of all trenches and backhoe lines;
(5) Restoration of the excavation site to city specifications; and
(6) Restoration of all landscaping and other affected structures such as sprinkler systems, erosion
control devices and mailboxes.
(c) All locate flags shall be removed during the cleanup process by the permit holder or his/her contractor at
the completion of the work.
(d) Restoration must be made in a timely manner as specified by approved public works schedules and to the
satisfaction of the director.
(Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 15, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.146 Locating of underground facilities
(a) All pipelines, cables, wiring, or other underground facilities that are beneath the surface of the right-ofway
must be identified by a sign or a marker, or by other notification procedures, to the appropriate entities, so
that all persons in the area and desiring to excavate may locate the underground facility. Such signs, markers and
other notification devices must contain all necessary information so that all persons desiring to excavate may
comply with the provisions of the Underground Facility Damage Prevention and Safety Act (section 251.001 et
seq. of the Texas Utilities Code, as amended). Where applicable such signs and markers shall be placed in
accordance with state and federal requirements. The markers and signs must be maintained by the utility in a
manner that is not unsightly or in a state of disrepair.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 216/652
(b) Any person installing, maintaining, or locating any facilities within any right-of-way in the city must
ascertain if there are facilities in that area, and must comply with the provisions of the Underground Facility
Damage Prevention and Safety Act prior to commencing any work under a permit issued by the city.
(c) If any of the provisions of this division are not followed, the director may revoke a permit. If a person has
not followed the terms and conditions of this division in work done pursuant to a prior permit, new permits may
be denied or additional terms required.
(Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 16, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.147 Police powers of city
An agency's or public infrastructure contractor's rights hereunder are subject to the police power of the city,
which includes, but is not limited to, the power to adopt and enforce ordinances, including amendments to this
division, necessary to protect the safety, health, and welfare of the public. Agencies and public infrastructure
contractors shall comply with all applicable laws and ordinances enacted, or hereafter enacted, by the city or any
other legally constituted governmental unit having lawful jurisdiction over the subject matter hereof. The city
reserves the right to exercise its police powers, notwithstanding anything in this division or a permit to the
contrary. Any conflict between the provisions of this division or a permit and any other present or future lawful
exercise of the city's police powers shall be resolved in favor of the latter. (Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 17,
adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.148 City's priority over other uses
(a) In the exercise of governmental functions, the city has first priority over all other uses of the public rightsof-
way. The city reserves the right to lay sewer, gas, water, and other pipelines or cables and conduits, and to do
underground and overhead work, and attachments, restructuring, or changes in aerial facilities, in, across, along,
over, or under a public street, alley, or public rights-of-way occupied by an agency or public infrastructure
contractor, and to change the curb, sidewalks, or the grade of streets.
(b) The agency or public infrastructure contractor must relocate its facilities, within a reasonable time, as
determined by the city, at its own expense, prior to the start of construction of a city project. Failure to comply
with this provision shall subject the agency or public infrastructure contractor to the enforcement provisions
contained herein.
(Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 18, adopted 3/6/01)
Sec. 3.11.149 Abandonment and removal of facilities
(a) If a registration is not renewed, and subject to sixty (60) days' notification to the agency or public
infrastructure contractor, all facilities owned by the agency or public infrastructure contractor within the city will
be deemed to have been abandoned and shall become the property of the city.
(b) Any agency or public infrastructure contractor that intends to discontinue use of any facilities within the
public rights-of-way shall notify the city engineer in writing of the intent to discontinue use. Such notice shall
describe the facilities for which the use is to be discontinued, and a date of discontinuance of use, which date
shall not be less than thirty (30) days from the date such notice is submitted to the city engineer. The city, in its
sole discretion, may accept dedication of the facilities to be abandoned, or require the agency or public
infrastructure contractor, at the agency's or public infrastructure contractor's sole cost and expense, to remove the
facilities to be abandoned, without interfering with any other right-of-way facility. The agency or public
infrastructure contractor may not remove, destroy, or permanently disable any such facilities without prior
written authorization from the city.
(Ordinance 01-03-235, sec. 19, adopted 3/6/01)
