https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 304/652
(13) All others not listed: $250.00.
(b) Permits renewed after the expiration date but before the permit has been suspended or revoked shall be
assessed a late fee of $25.00.
(c) Permits reinstated following suspension shall be assessed a reinstatement fee of $150.00.
(d) A seasonal fee applies to:
(1) Food establishments that operate for less than seven months of a calendar year due to the type
of products sold; or
(2) Vendors at a farmer's market selling produce or other unprepared raw foods.
(e) The city manager may waive or reduce fees for food establishments requiring a permit solely for city
sponsored events.
(Ordinance 10-01-757, sec. 4, adopted 1/12/10)
Sec. 6.03.004 Review of plans
(a) Whenever a food establishment is constructed or extensively remodeled and whenever an existing
structure is converted to use as a food establishment, properly prepared plans and specifications for such
construction, remodeling or conversion shall be submitted to the city for review before work is begun. Extensive
remodeling means that 20% or greater of the area of the food establishment is to be remodeled. The plans and
specifications shall indicate the proposed layout, equipment arrangement, mechanical plans and construction of
materials of work areas, and the type and model of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. The plans and
specifications will be approved by the city if they meet the requirements of the rules in this article. The approved
plans and specifications must be followed in construction, remodeling or conversion.
(b) Failure to follow the approved plans and specifications may result in a permit denial, suspension, or
revocation.
(Ordinance 10-01-757, sec. 5, adopted 1/12/10)
Sec. 6.03.005 Suspension of permit
(a) The city may, without warning, notice, or hearing suspend any permit to operate a food establishment if
the authorized agent or employee of the city determines the operation of the food establishment constitutes an
imminent hazard to public health. Suspension is effective upon service of the notice required by section
6.03.007(a) of this article. Whenever a permit is suspended, the holder of the permit shall be afforded an
opportunity for a hearing as set forth in section 6.03.007(b) of this article.
(b) Whenever a permit is suspended, the holder of the permit or the person in charge shall be notified in
writing that the permit is, upon service of the notice, immediately suspended and that an opportunity for a
hearing will be provided if a request for hearing is made according to the provisions set forth in section
6.03.007(b) of this article. If no written request for a hearing is filed within ten days, the suspension is sustained.
The city may end the suspension at any time by providing written notification to the holder of the permit if
reasons for suspension no longer exist.
(c) The city may suspend a permit that has expired. Prior to the suspension under this subsection, the city shall
notify the holder of the permit or the person in charge, in writing, that the permit is subject to suspension if not
renewed within ten days. The holder of the permit or the person in charge may request a hearing according to the
provisions set forth in section 6.03.007(b) of this article if the holder of the permit or the person in charge
believes the city has wrongly determined the permit to be expired.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 305/652
(d) When a permit is suspended, food operations shall immediately cease.
(Ordinance 10-01-757, sec. 6, adopted 1/12/10)
Sec. 6.03.006 Revocation of permit
(a) The city may, after providing opportunity for a hearing, revoke a permit for serious or repeated violations
of any of the requirements of these rules or for interference with the city in the performance of its duties. Prior to
revocation, the city shall notify the holder of the permit or the person in charge, in writing, of the reason for
which the permit is subject to revocation and that the permit shall be revoked at the end of the ten days following
service of such notice unless a written request for hearing is made according to the provisions set forth in section
6.03.007(b) of this article.
(b) A permit that has been suspended for more than thirty days is subject to suspension.
(c) If no request for hearing is filed within the ten-day period, the revocation of the permit becomes final.
(Ordinance 10-01-757, sec. 7, adopted 1/12/10)
Sec. 6.03.007 Administrative process
(a) A notice as required in this article is properly served when it is delivered to the holder of the permit or the
person in charge, or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known
address of the holder of the permit. A copy of the notice shall be filed in the records of the regulatory authority.
(b) Any hearing conducted pursuant to this article shall be done pursuant to the administrative hearing process
as set forth in article 7.02 of this code.
(1) The administrative hearing officer shall have no authority to waive, alter or amend any
requirements of this article.
(2) An appeal filed pursuant to this section shall have no effect on the ability of the city to enforce
any rule, ordinance, law, or police regulation and shall not stay any proceedings initiated by the city.
(3) The appellate procedures set forth in this section are administrative remedies available to any
person aggrieved by an order, decision or determination made by an authorized agent or employee.
(Ordinance 10-01-757, sec. 8, adopted 1/12/10)
Secs. 6.03.008–6.03.0030 Reserved
Division 2. Certified Food Protection Manager
Sec. 6.03.031 Generally
(a) Every food establishment that has employees whose work brings them in contact with the handling of
food, utensils, or food service equipment shall have a certified food protection manager.
(1) A certified food protection manager is a manager or person in charge who has completed a food
protection management class from any accredited institution or firm of their choice as recognized by
the department of state health services.
(2) A certified food protection manager is required to be on duty at all times for each food
establishment.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 306/652
(3) If a food establishment does not meet the requirements for a certified food protection manager
because of the termination or transfer of certified personnel, the food establishment shall employ
another certified food protection manager within 45 days after such termination or transfer.
(b) Food establishments that serve, sell, or distribute only prepackaged foods and nonpotentially hazardous
beverages, and temporary food establishments are exempt from this division.
(Ordinance 10-01-757, sec. 11, adopted 1/12/10)
Sec. 6.03.032 Registration and fees
All certified food protection managers operating at food establishments within the city must register with the
city on forms provided by the city. The registration fee for certified food protection managers to register with the
city is $30.00. (Ordinance 10-01-757, sec. 12, adopted 1/12/10)
ARTICLE 6.04 RESERVED*
ARTICLE 6.05 WEEDS, RUBBISH AND OTHER UNSANITARY OR OBJECTIONABLE
CONDITIONS*
Sec. 6.05.001 Prohibition against high weeds
(a) Definitions:
Person. Any person, firm, partnership, corporation, company, organization or business entity of any kind.
Premises. The lot, plot, ground, yard, or parcel of land, plus the front or side parkway between the property line
or sidewalk and the curb or traveled-way, and the rear or side parkway between the property line and the
centerline of an adjacent alley.
Weeds. Uncultivated or cultivated vegetation, including grass, having a height in excess of twelve (12) inches.
(b) A person commits an offense if such person permits, suffers or allows weeds on any premises under his
ownership, control or supervision within the city limits.
(c) For violations occurring on contiguous lots, plots, or parcels of land, owned by the same person, each
violation on a separate lot, plot, or parcel of land is a separate offense.
(d) It shall be a defense to prosecution under this section that:
(1) The premises are zoned agricultural, the weeds on the premises constitute an agricultural crop,
and the weeds are located at a distance of greater than fifty (50) feet from any adjacent property
under different ownership and any adjacent or contiguous street right-of-way, alley, utility easement
or other public right-of-way;
(2) The weeds are located in an area of natural historic of scientific significance, provided that:
(A) A declaration of such significance describing the particular plant or plant varieties being
preserved, shall be submitted by the occupant or owner of the property to the city manager;
(B) A management plan describing how such property will be maintained in such a manner
so as to preclude fire hazards and creation of conditions inimical to the public health. Such
management plan shall be approved by the city manager; and
(C) Such property shall be maintained in accordance with the submitted management plan; or
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 307/652
(3) The weeds constitute vegetation which is decorative flowers, vines, bushes, shrubs, plants or
trees, provided that such vegetation is maintained in a manner as not to be a fire hazard.
Sec. 6.05.002 Prohibition against vegetation in alleys, streets, and sidewalks
(a) A person commits an offense if such person permits, suffers, or allows any vegetation, including, but not
limited to, trees, shrubbery, bushes, and vines, growing on premises owned or controlled by such person to
project across the property line into the right-of-way of an alley, street, or sidewalk.
(b) It shall be a defense to prosecution that no part of the vegetation projected over or into the right-of-way of
the alley, street, or sidewalk at a height of less than fifteen (15) feet above the ground.
Sec. 6.05.003 Abatement procedures and placement of a privileged lien for the removal of high weeds
(a) This section applies only if the city desires to perfect a lien for any expenses incurred in abating high
weeds.
(b) After discovery of high weeds on any premises within the city, the city shall issue a notice of a violation.
The notice must be given in accordance with section 342.006 of the Texas Health and Safety Code.
(c) If the high weeds are not abated within ten (10) days and notice to the owner of the property involved has
been given, the city shall have full authority to abate such nuisance or cause same to be abated.
(1) Such abatement shall be performed at the expense of the city for the account of the owners of
the property.
(2) All such expenses incurred in abating such nuisance shall be assessed on and against the
premises on which said expenses and shall include the actual costs of abating the nuisance and an
administrative fee of $125.00.
(3) On filing with the county clerk, a statement signed by the mayor, the city manager, the director
of a city department charged with enforcing this article, or the managing director of financial services
of expenses actually incurred in abating such high weeds plus administrative fees, the city shall have
a lien against the premises to the extent of the expenses and administrative fees incurred. Such lien
shall be a privileged lien, second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements. Interest at the
rate of ten percent (10%) compounded annually shall accrue on the expenses and fees secured by the
lien. Interest shall be calculated from the date the expenses secured by the lien were incurred by the
city.
(4) For such expenditures and interest, the city attorney may settle such liens with the property
owner or institute suit to foreclose said lien, and a statement of expenses aforesaid, or certified copy
thereof, shall be prima facie proof of the amount expended in such work in abatement and the
reasonableness thereof.
(Ordinance 08-06-662 adopted 6/10/08)
(d) The city may abate, without notice, weeds that have: (1) grown higher than 36 inches; and (2) are an
immediate danger to the health, life or safety to any person. Not later than the 10th day after the date the city
abates weeds pursuant to this subsection, the city shall give notice to the property owner in accordance with
section 342.006 of the Texas Health and Safety Code. The notice shall contain: (1) an identification, which is not
required to be a legal description, of the property; (2) a description of the violations of the ordinance that
occurred on the property; (3) a statement that the municipality abated the weeds; and (4) an explanation of the
property owner's right to request an administrative hearing about the municipality's abatement of the weeds.
Such administrative hearing shall be conducted as follows:
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 308/652
(1) Such hearing shall be in the form of an administration adjudication hearing pursuant to the
administrative hearing process as established by article 7.02.
(2) The property owner must request a hearing not later than the 30th day after the date of the
abatement of the weeds;
(3) A hearing shall be conducted not later than the 20th day after the date a request for a hearing is
filed, unless the administrative hearing officer continues the matter for good cause.
(Ordinance 09-08-734 adopted 8/18/09)
Sec. 6.05.004 Penalty provision
Any person violating this, as it exists or may be amended, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon
conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine not to exceed the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00), except if the
violation was found to be committed intentionally, knowingly, recklessly, or with criminal negligence, then the
person shall be punished by a fine not exceeding two thousand and no/100 dollars ($2,000.00). A second
conviction, including convictions for separate premises, within any sixty-month period shall have a minimum
fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00) Each continuing day's violation under this article shall constitute a
separate offense. The penal provisions imposed under this article shall not preclude the city from filing suit to
enjoin the violation. The city retains all legal rights and remedies available to it pursuant to local, state and
federal law. (Ordinance 08-06-662 adopted 6/10/08)
CHAPTER 7
MUNICIPAL COURT
ARTICLE 7.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
Sec. 7.01.001 State penal code and trial procedures adopted
The Penal Code, Code of Criminal Procedure and Revised Civil Statutes of the state defining criminal offenses
and prescribing the rules and regulations of trials thereunder are hereby adopted by the city as to any offense
defined therein committed within the corporate limits of the city of which the corporation court has jurisdiction,
and all rules and regulations contained therein, and the rules pertaining to the justice courts, as therein
prescribed, shall be the rules and regulations as to the procedure in said corporation court. (1962 Code, art. 1)
State law reference–Procedures for processing cases within criminal jurisdiction of municipal court, Tex. Code Crim. Proc. ch. 45.
Sec. 7.01.002 Establishment of a municipal court of record
(a) In accordance with chapter 30 of the Texas Government Code, there is hereby created a municipal court of
record to be designated as the City Municipal Court of Record No. 1.
(b) Municipal Court of Record No. 1 and any municipal court of record subsequently established hereunder
shall have:
(1) Jurisdiction provided by law for municipal courts;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 309/652
(2) Jurisdiction over criminal cases arising under ordinances authorized by sections 215.072,
217.042, 341.903, and 551.002, of the Texas Local Government Code;
(3) Civil jurisdiction to enforce a municipal ordinance adopted under subchapter A, chapter 214 of
the Texas Local Government Code;
(4) Civil jurisdiction to enforce a municipal ordinance adopted under subchapter E, chapter 683 of
the Texas Transportation Code;
(5) Concurrent jurisdiction with a district or a county court at law under subchapter B, chapter 54
of the Texas Local Government Code, within the municipality's territorial limits and property owned
by the municipality located in the municipality's extraterritorial jurisdiction for the purpose of
enforcing health and safety and nuisance abatement ordinances;
(6) Appellate jurisdiction from administrative hearings conducted under section 54.044 of the
Texas Local Government Code or as otherwise provided by law;
(7) Authority to issue:
(A) Search warrants for the purpose of investigating a health and safety or nuisance
abatement ordinance violation; and
(B) Seizure warrants for the purpose of securing, removing, or demolishing the offending
property and removing the debris from the premises; and
(8) Jurisdiction as otherwise provided by law.
(c) A municipal court of record created under this article has no term and may sit at any time for the
transaction of business of the court.
Sec. 7.01.003 Other terms and laws applicable to the municipal court of record
(a) Where the term municipal court or corporation court is used in this code, it shall mean the municipal court
of record created under this article.
(b) Any provision of law that is applicable to a municipal court shall be applicable to a municipal court of
record created under this article unless the provision is in conflict or inconsistent with chapter 30 of the Texas
Government Code.
Sec. 7.01.004 The clerk of the court
(a) The city manager shall appoint the clerk of the municipal court who may hire, direct, and remove, in
accordance with applicable city policies, the personnel authorized in the city's annual budget for the clerk's
office. The clerk shall perform the duties in accordance with law.
(b) The clerk shall keep the records of the municipal court of record, issue process, and generally perform the
duties that a clerk of a county court at law exercising criminal jurisdiction performs for that court. The clerk
shall maintain an index of all court judgments in the same manner as county clerks are required by law to
prepare for criminal cases arising in county courts.
(c) Section 30.00009(c) of the Texas Government Code does not apply.
(d) The clerk serves under the direction of the city manager, except that when court is in session the clerk and
other court personnel perform their duties under the direction and control of the presiding judge.
Sec. 7.01.005 Court reporter
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 310/652
(a) Instead of providing a court reporter at trial or during any other court proceeding, proceedings in a
municipal court of record may be recorded by a good quality recording device.
(b) Upon request of the judge or upon request of one of the parties to a trial, proceedings of the municipal
court of record, including sworn trial testimony and motions before the court, shall be recorded.
(c) Proceedings which are appealed from a case that was recorded pursuant to this section shall be transcribed
from the recording by an official court reporter selected by the presiding judge.
(d) Except as modified in this section, the recording procedures and record retention requirements set forth in
chapter 30 of the Texas Government Code shall apply.
(Ordinance 09-09-741 adopted 9/15/09)
ARTICLE 7.02 ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING PROCESS
Sec. 7.02.001 Establishment
An administrative hearing process (AHP) is hereby adopted, along with the following procedures and processes,
to provide for administrative adjudication hearings for the city. (Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 1, adopted 4/8/08)
Sec. 7.02.002 Application and construction of article
(a) Unless otherwise specifically provided by ordinance, this article will govern all matters that are appealable
to an administrative adjudication hearing or to the AHP by any ordinance of the city.
(b) Unless otherwise specifically provided by ordinance, administrative hearings in all cases subject to the
AHP shall be conducted in accordance with the following procedures and processes; provided that the
administrative hearing officer may, by order, modify and supplement the requirements of this article to promote
the fair and efficient handling of the case and to facilitate resolution of issues, if doing so does not prejudice the
rights of any party or contravene applicable ordinances.
(Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 2, adopted 4/8/08)
Sec. 7.02.003 Definitions
Administrative hearing officer. The municipal court judge of the Royse City Municipal Court. (Ordinance 08-
07-672 adopted 7/15/08)
AHP. The administrative hearing process.
Association. A government or governmental subdivision or agency, trust, partnership, or two or more persons
having a joint or common economic interest.
Authorized representative. An attorney authorized to practice law in the state.
Party. A person or the city named, or admitted to participate, in a case before the administrative hearing officer.
Person. Any individual, representative, corporation, or other association.
Pleading. A written document submitted by a party, or a person seeking to participate in a case as a party, which
addresses matters involved in the case.
(Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 3, adopted 4/8/08)
Sec. 7.02.004 Request for hearing
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 311/652
(a) The ordinance granting a right to an appeal under the AHP shall dictate who can appeal and when an
appeal can be made.
(b) A party authorized to make an appeal shall submit a complaint or petition to the clerk of the municipal
court. Such complaint or petition shall describe the circumstances giving rise to such appeal and shall contain
the following:
(1) The name of the party making the appeal;
(2) A concise statement of facts; and
(3) A clear statement of the type of relief, action, or order desired, and identification of the specific
grounds supporting the relief requested.
(c) A party filing an appeal shall post an appellate filing fee of $75.00.
(1) If the administrative hearing officer determines that the party required to post such fee is
indigent and financially unable to pay the fee, the administrative hearing officer may reduce or waive
the fee.
(2) The administrative hearing officer shall determine the manner in which a party applies for a
waiver or reduction of the fee.
(3) If a complete ruling in favor of the person filing the appeal is ordered by the administrative
hearing officer, the person filing the appeal shall be entitled to a refund of the $75.00 appellate filing
fee.
(d) The clerk of the municipal court shall assign a cause number and set a hearing on the matter for the next
available municipal court docket.
(Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 4, adopted 4/8/08)
Sec. 7.02.005 Hearing officer's powers, duties and functions
An administrative hearing officer shall have the following powers, duties and functions:
(1) To conduct a full, fair, and impartial hearing;
(2) Maintain order;
(3) To administer oaths;
(4) To rule on motions;
(5) To take testimony, including the power to question witnesses and examine evidence offered;
(6) To admit or deny party status;
(7) To make rulings on items specified by the ordinance granting a right to an appeal under the
AHP;
(8) To rule on questions of evidence;
(9) To rule on questions of discovery;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 312/652
(10) To issue orders compelling the attendance of witnesses and the production of documents,
which order may be enforced by the administrative hearing officer in the same manner as if the
administrative hearing officer were sitting as a judge of the municipal court;
(11) Limit irrelevant, immaterial, and unduly repetitious testimony and reasonably limit the time
for presentations;
(12) Where appropriate and justified by party or representative behavior, and after notice an
opportunity for a hearing, issue an order:
(A) Disallowing further discovery of any kind or of a particular kind by the offending party;
(B) Holding that designated facts be considered admitted for purposes of the proceeding;
(C) Disallowing in whole or in part requests for relief by the offending party and excluding
evidence in support of those requests; and
(D) Striking pleadings or testimony, or both, in whole or in part.
(Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 5, adopted 4/8/08)
Sec. 7.02.006 Representation of parties
(a) A party may represent himself or herself, or may appear by authorized representative.
(b) All party corporations or associations appear by authorized representative.
(Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 6, adopted 4/8/08)
Sec. 7.02.007 Filing and serving documents
(a) The original of all pleadings and other documents requesting action or relief in a hearing before the
administrative hearing officer shall be filed with the clerk of the municipal court.
(b) Discovery requests and deposition notices to be served on parties and responses and objections to
discovery requests shall not be filed with clerk of the municipal court, unless the administrative hearing officer
specifies otherwise.
(c) Motions requesting relief in a discovery dispute shall be accompanied by only those portions of discovery
materials relevant to the dispute.
(d) Any party filing documents shall provide a copy to each party or the party's authorized representative and
shall include a certificate of service that certifies compliance with this section.
(Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 7, adopted 4/8/08)
Sec. 7.02.008 Discovery
(a) Parties may obtain discovery pursuant to the rule 190.2 of the Texas Rules of Civil Procedure, except as
specifically modified by order of the administrative hearing officer or the AHP.
(b) Discovery may commence upon requesting a hearing pursuant to section 7.02.004 of the AHP.
(c) Requests for subpoenas or orders compelling attendance or action by others shall be submitted to the
administrative hearing officer.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 313/652
(d) The administrative hearing officer may establish deadlines and limitations on discovery.
(e) Objections to discovery shall be filed in accordance with the Texas Rules of Civil Procedure.
(Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 8, adopted 4/8/08)
Sec. 7.02.009 Orders
(a) The administrative hearing officer has broad authority to issue orders to regulate the conduct of the
proceeding, rule on motions., establish deadlines, clarify the scope of the proceeding, schedule and conduct
prehearing or posthearing conferences for any purpose related to any matter in the case, set out additional
requirements for participation in the case, and take any other steps conducive to a fair and efficient process in the
contested case.
(b) The administrative hearing officer may order the consolidation of dockets or joint hearings on dockets if
there are common issues of law or fact, and consolidation or joint hearing will aid the fair and efficient handling
of contested matters. The administrative hearing officer may order severance of issues if separate hearings on
such issues will aid the fair and efficient handling of contested matters.
(c) Following a final hearing on a case, the administrative hearing officer shall:
(1) Issue a written ruling or determination on the case;
(2) Issue the amount of civil penalties, if allowed by the ordinance granting a right to an appeal
under the AHP, fees and court costs;
(3) Mail or deliver a copy of such order to each party; and
(4) Notify the parties of the right to appeal to the district court before the thirtieth (30th) day after
the date the administrative hearing officer's order is filed.
(d) All orders shall be filed with the clerk of the municipal court and shall be kept in a separate index and file.
The order may be recorded using microfilm, microfiche, or data processing techniques.
(Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 9, adopted 4/8/08)
Sec. 7.02.010 Procedures at administrative hearing
(a) The standard of proof shall be that the party whose action or determination is being appealed shall prove
their action or determination by a preponderance of the evidence.
(b) The formal rules of evidence, while instructive, do not apply to a hearing under the AHP, and relevant
evidence will be admitted if the hearing officer finds that evidence is of that quality which reasonable persons
are accustomed to rely on in the conduct of serious affairs, regardless of the existence of any common law or
statutory rule to the contrary.
(c) Each party shall have the right to call and examine witnesses, to introduce exhibits, to cross-examine
opposing witnesses on any matter relevant to the issues, and to rebut the opposing party's evidence.
(d) The administrative hearing officer may examine any witness and may consider any evidence offered by a
witness.
(e) The administrative hearing officer shall be the decider of facts under the AHP.
(Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 10, adopted 4/8/08)
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 314/652
Sec. 7.02.011 Making a record of a hearing
(a) The administrative hearing officer is not required to make a record of testimony in a hearing unless a party
requests in writing that a record be made.
(b) Recordings of hearings.
(1) Upon written request by a party for a record to be made, the administrative hearing officer shall
record the hearing by a good quality electronic recording device.
(2) A party may, at their expense, have a certified court reporter present in the hearing room during
the proceedings. If such party wishes for the certified court reporter to make the official record of the
hearing, the court reporter must meet the qualifications provided by law for official court reporters
and such court reporter must record the proceedings in the same manner as required for civil trials in
the state.
(3) A recording of a hearing under the AHP shall be preserved for not less than ninety (90) days
after the conclusion of the hearing, until a final disposition of the proceeding, or otherwise as
required by law.
(c) Transcriptions.
(1) Either party or any other person can request a transcription of the electronic recording.
(2) The transcription shall be prepared from the recording of the administrative hearing by a court
reporter or other person authorized by the administrative hearing officer to transcribe proceedings.
The court reporter or other person who prepares the transcription of the electronic recording is not
required to have been present at the hearing when the recording took place.
(3) The person requesting the transcription shall be responsible for the cost of preparing the
transcription of the electronic recording. Before the recorded proceedings are transcribed, the person
requesting the transcription shall post a cash deposit with the clerk of the municipal court for the
estimated cost of preparing the transcription, as determined by the clerk. If the decision of the hearing
officer is fully reversed on appeal, the clerk shall refund all amounts paid for the transcription.
(4) [If] the administrative hearing officer determines that a party requesting a transcript for
appellate purposes is indigent and financially unable to pay the costs of preparation, the
administrative hearing officer may order a waiver of those costs.
(Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 11, adopted 4/8/08)
Sec. 7.02.012 Default proceedings, dismissal proceedings and summary disposition
(a) If a party who does not have the burden of proof fails to appear for a hearing, the administrative hearing
officer may proceed in the party's absence, provided that the administrative hearing officer is satisfied that
proper notice had been given.
(b) If a party filing an appeal under the AHP fails to prosecute the case, the administrative hearing officer may
dismiss the case for want of prosecution after giving such party notice and an opportunity for a hearing.
(c) The administrative hearing officer may also dismiss a case for the following reasons:
(1) Lack of ordinance authorizing the administrative hearing officer to conduct the proceeding;
(2) Mootness of the cause;
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 315/652
(3) Failure to state a claim for which relief can be granted; or
(4) Unnecessary duplication of proceedings.
(d) In response to a party's motion or after the administrative hearing officer notifies the parties of an intent to
dispose of a case by summary disposition and allows time for responses, the administrative hearing officer may
issue a decision or final order resolving the case without evidentiary hearing, if the pleadings, affidavits,
materials obtained by discovery, admissions, matters officially noticed, stipulations, or evidence of record show
there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that a party is entitled to a decision in its favor as a matter of
law.
(Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 12, adopted 4/8/08)
Sec. 7.02.013 Enforcement of orders
The city attorney may enforce an order issued under the AHP by filing a civil suit for the collection of any
penalty, fees, and/or costs and by obtaining an injunction that prohibits specific conduct that violates an order or
that requires specific conduct necessary for compliance with an order. (Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 13, adopted
4/8/08)
Sec. 7.02.014 Judicial review
(a) Any party aggrieved by a decision under the AHP may present a petition to a district court, duly verified,
setting forth that the decision is illegal, in whole or in part, and specifying the grounds of the illegality. The
petition must be presented to the court within 30 days after the date a copy of the final decision was issued by
the administrative hearing officer.
(b) On presentation of the petition, the court may allow a writ of certiorari directed to the administrative
hearing officer to review the decision of the administrative hearing officer and shall prescribe in the writ the
time, which may not be less than 10 days, within which a return on the writ must be made and served on the
relator or the relator's attorney.
(c) The administrative hearing officer may not be required to return the original papers acted on by it. It is
sufficient for the administrative hearing officer to return certified or sworn copies of the papers or of parts of the
papers as may be called for by the writ.
(d) The return must concisely set forth other facts as may be pertinent and material to show the grounds for
the decision appealed from and shall be verified.
(e) The district court's review shall be limited to a hearing under the substantial evidence rule. The court may
reverse or affirm, in whole or in part, or may modify the decision brought up for review.
(f) Costs may not be allowed against the administrative hearing officer.
(g) If the decision of the administrative hearing officer is affirmed or not substantially reversed but only
modified, the district court may allow to the city all attorney's fees and other costs and expenses incurred by it
and shall enter a judgment for those items.
(Ordinance 08-04-653, sec. 14, adopted 4/8/08)
