are on file in the city secretary's office and are specifically saved from repeal upon adoption of the Code of
Ordinances. (Ordinance adopting Code)
Secs. 12.05.042–12.05.080 Reserved
Division 3. Parking Trucks, Trailers or Commercial Vehicles or Equipment in Residential Zones
Sec. 12.05.081 Definitions
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in
this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Boat trailer. A trailer or semitrailer which is designed and constructed to carry a sailboat, motorboat or other
vessel used upon any body of water.
Bus. Every motor vehicle designed for carrying more than 10 passengers and used for the transportation of
persons, and/or every motor vehicle, other than a taxicab, designed and used for the transportation of persons for
compensation.
Commercial motor vehicle. Any motor vehicle (other than a motorcycle or passenger car) designed or used
primarily for the transportation of property, including any passenger car which has been reconstructed so as to be
used and which is being used primarily for delivery purposes, with the exception of passenger cars used in the
delivery of the United States mail.
Farm tractor. Every motor vehicle designed and used primarily as a farm implement for, among other things,
drawing plows, mowing machines and other implements of husbandry.
House trailer. A trailer or semitrailer which is designed, constructed and equipped as a dwelling place, living
abode and/or sleeping place (either permanently or temporarily) and is equipped for use as a conveyance on
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 422/652
streets and highways, and shall include, without limitation, those vehicles commonly known as recreational
vehicles.
Implement of husbandry. Every vehicle designed and adapted for use as a farm implement, machinery or tool
used in tilling the soil, but shall not include any passenger car or truck.
Motor home. Every vehicle designed, constructed and equipped as a dwelling place, living abode and/or sleeping
place (either permanently or temporarily) and equipped for use as a conveyance on streets and highways.
Pole trailer. Every vehicle without motor power designed to be drawn by another vehicle and attached to the
towing vehicle by means of a reach or pole or being boomed or otherwise secured to the towing vehicle and
ordinarily used for transporting long or irregularly shaped loads such as poles, pipes or structural members
capable, generally, of sustaining themselves as beams between the supporting connections.
Semitrailer. Every vehicle with or without motive power, other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons
or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that some part of its weight and load rests
upon or is carried by another vehicle.
Special mobile equipment. Every vehicle not designed or used primarily for the transportation of persons or
property and only incidentally operated or moved over a highway, including but not limited to ditch-digging
apparatus, well-boring apparatus and road construction and maintenance machinery, including but not limited to
asphalt spreaders, bituminous mixers, bucket loaders, tractors other than truck tractors, ditchers, leveling
graders, finishing machines, motor graders, road rollers, scarifiers, earth-moving carry-alls and scrapers, power
shovels and draglines, and self-propelled cranes and earth-moving equipment. The term does not include house
trailers, dump trucks, truck-mounted transit mixers, cranes or shovels or other vehicles designed for the
transportation of persons or property to which machinery has been attached.
Trailer. Every vehicle with or without motive power, other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons or
property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that no part of its weight and that of its load
rests upon or is carried by another vehicle.
Truck. Every motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the transportation of property.
Truck tractor. Every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and not so
constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn.
(Ordinance 06-05-505, sec. 3, adopted 5/16/06)
Sec. 12.05.082 Penalty
Any person, firm, corporation or business entity violating this division shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor,
and upon conviction thereof shall be fined a sum not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each continuing
day's violation under this division shall constitute a separate offense. The penal provisions imposed under this
division shall not preclude the city from filing suit to enjoin the violation. The city retains all legal rights and
remedies available to it pursuant to local, state and federal law. (Ordinance 06-05-505, sec. 5, adopted 5/16/06)
Sec. 12.05.083 Prohibitions; exceptions
(a) Prohibitions.
(1) It shall be unlawful for any person to park, stop and/or stand any truck with a manufacturer's
rated carrying capacity in excess of one (1) ton according to the manufacturer's classification, motor
home, bus, trailer, semitrailer, pole trailer, truck tractor, house trailer, boat trailer, special mobile
equipment, commercial motor vehicle, farm tractor or implement of husbandry upon any public
street, highway, alley or public right-of-way between any street and alley within any part of the city
classified by the city zoning ordinance as a residentially zoned district.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 423/652
(2) No parking space, garage, carport or other vehicle storage space or structure located on private
property in a residentially zoned district shall be used for the storage of any truck with a
manufacturer's rated carrying capacity in excess of one (1) ton according to the manufacturer's
classification, or any motor home, bus, trailer, semitrailer, pole trailer, truck tractor, house trailer,
special mobile equipment, commercial motor vehicle, farm tractor or implement of husbandry.
(3) No truck with a manufacturer's rated carrying capacity in excess of one (1) ton according to the
manufacturer's classification or any motor home, bus, trailer, semitrailer, pole trailer, truck tractor,
house trailer, special mobile equipment, commercial motor vehicle, farm tractor, implement of
husbandry, boat or other aquatic vehicle, or camper trailer shall be parked or stored within the
required front yard. The parking or storage in the rear yard is limited to a maximum of one (1)
pleasure boat or other aquatic vehicle and one (1) unoccupied trailer, motor home or house trailer
designed for recreational use and not to exceed twenty-four feet (24') in length. This restriction shall
not apply to the storage of a boat or other aquatic vehicle, or other vehicle, in a fully enclosed
building.
(4) Unless otherwise provided herein, the parking of any vehicle within any part of a front yard
shall be prohibited, except in driveways.
(b) Exceptions.
(1) This section shall not prevent the parking, stopping and/or standing of the above-described
vehicles and/or trailers upon any public street, highway or alley in any such residentially zoned areas
for the purpose of expeditiously loading and unloading passengers, freight or merchandise, or the
expeditious delivery of a service or product.
(2) One occupied motor home or house trailer per calendar year may be parked in the driveway of
a residential lot or on a public street within a residentially zoned district by a guest of the host
premises on a temporary basis not to exceed fourteen (14) consecutive days.
(Ordinance 06-05-505, sec. 4, adopted 5/16/06)
(3) This section shall not prevent the parking and/or storage of boats on trailers, motor homes,
house trailers, and other recreational vehicles on trailers upon any paved driveway provided that the
vehicle including the trailer is no more than 25 feet long and/or 12 feet tall and provided that
additional space on a paved driveway is available for two motor vehicles. Boats and other
recreational vehicles included in this exception must have current registration stickers if such stickers
are required by the state. (Ordinance 11-10-855 adopted 10/11/11)
(c) Presumption that vehicle owner is responsible for offense. When any truck, motor home, bus, trailer,
semitrailer, pole trailer, truck tractor, boat trailer, house trailer, special mobile equipment, commercial motor
vehicle, farm tractor or implement of husbandry is parked, stopped or standing in violation of this division, such
fact shall be prima facie proof that the registered owner of the truck, motor home, bus, trailer, semitrailer, pole
trailer, truck tractor, boat trailer, house trailer, special mobile equipment, commercial motor vehicle, farm tractor
or implement of husbandry vehicle placed said vehicle, trailer and/or equipment in the area. (Ordinance 06-05-
505, sec. 4, adopted 5/16/06)
ARTICLE 12.06 COMMERCIAL VEHICLES; TRUCK ROUTES*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 12.06.001 Ready-mixed concrete trucks
(a) Definition; ready-mixed concrete designated perishable product.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 424/652
(1) In this section, “ready-mixed concrete truck” means:
(A) A vehicle designed exclusively to transport or manufacture ready-mixed concrete and
includes a vehicle designed exclusively to transport and manufacture ready-mixed concrete; or
(B) A concrete pump truck.
(2) Ready-mixed concrete is a perishable product.
(b) Weight limits; equipment; bond.
(1) The city council has determined that public highways under its jurisdiction are insufficient to
carry a load authorized by section 622.012 of the Transportation Code, and hereby prescribes rules
governing the operation of ready-mixed concrete trucks over a public highway maintained by the
city.
(2) No person may operate a ready-mixed concrete truck over a public highway maintained by the
municipality in violation of any of the following rules:
(A) The tandem axle load is heavier than 38,000 pounds;
(B) The single axle load is heavier than 12,000 pounds; or
(C) The gross load is heavier than 50,000 pounds.
(D) The truck is equipped with a functioning device attached to the concrete chute which
traps any material in the chute and prevents it from spilling onto the roadway.
(E) The owner of a ready-mixed concrete truck must file a surety bond in the amount of
fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) with the city secretary, prior to operation of the truck over
a public highway maintained by the city, and conditioned that the owner of the truck will pay to
the city any damage to a highway caused by the operation of the truck with a tandem axle load
that is heavier than 34,000 pounds.
(Ordinance 01-09-258, secs. 34, 35, adopted 9/11/01)
Secs. 12.06.002–12.06.030 Reserved
Division 2. Truck Routes
Sec. 12.06.031 Penalty
Any person who shall violate any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and each
such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each day or portion thereof during which any
violation of any provision of this article is committed, continued, or permitted, and each violation shall be
punishable by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00). (Ordinance 95-06-48, sec. 6, adopted 6/13/95)
Sec. 12.06.032 Use required
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to operate upon any public street, highway, or alley
within the corporate limits of the city any commercial motor vehicle, truck, truck-tractor, or semitrailer, when
any such vehicle has a gross weight exceeding ten thousand pounds, unless that public street, highway, or alley
has been designated as a truck route. (Ordinance 95-06-48, sec. 1, adopted 6/13/95)
Sec. 12.06.033 Designation
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 425/652
The following are designated as truck routes:
(1) Interstate 30 and its service roads.
(2) Industrial Drive.
(3) State Highway 66 (Main Street).
(4) That portion of County Line Road east of State Highway 66.
(5) F.M. 1777 (Bulldog Boulevard).
(6) F.M. 548 (South Elm Street).
(7) F.M. 2453.
(8) F.M. 35.
(Ordinance 95-06-48, sec. 2, adopted 6/13/95)
Sec. 12.06.034 Parking of large commercial vehicles
The parking or standing of commercial vehicles over ten thousand (10,000) pounds gross weight upon any
highway, street, or alley within the corporate limits of the city is prohibited except upon those streets designated
in section 12.06.033 as truck routes. (Ordinance 95-06-48, sec. 3, adopted 6/13/95)
Sec. 12.06.035 Marking
The mayor shall be authorized to mark the routes established herein by the erection of “No Through Trucks”
signs on streets which are not designated as truck routes. (Ordinance 95-06-48, sec. 4, adopted 6/13/95)
Sec. 12.06.036 Defenses
It shall be a defense to prosecution under sections 12.06.032 and 12.06.034 that the driver of any truck had
departed from a designated truck route for the purpose of going directly to or from any business or residence
within the corporate limits of the city to either:
(1) Make a commercial delivery; or
(2) Unload a commercial consignment.
(Ordinance 95-06-48, sec. 5, adopted 6/13/95)
Secs. 12.06.037–12.06.070 Reserved
Division 3. Weight Limits
Sec. 12.06.071 Generally
(a) Maximum vehicle weight. It shall be unlawful for anyone to operate a commercial motor vehicle, trucktractor,
trailer or semitrailer on the public streets of the city with a load exceeding 7,000 pounds on any such
vehicle or train or combination of vehicles, and no motor vehicle, commercial vehicle, truck-tractor, trailer or
semitrailer on the public streets of the city having a greater weight than 600 pounds per inch width of tire upon
any wheel concentrated upon the surface of the highway shall be operated.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 426/652
(b) Permit. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, operate or move or for the owner to cause or permit to
be driven, operated or moved on any street in the city any vehicle or vehicles of a weight or character exceeding
the limitations provided in subsection (a) of this section; providing, however, where it is necessary to operate a
vehicle exceeding the requirements of this section, the mayor is hereby given authority to grant a special permit
for the use of the streets where such use will not injure the surface of the street used. When such permit is
granted, the operator will be given the routing by the mayor and the applicant shall pay a fee of one dollar
($1.00) for the permit to the city.
(c) Penalty. Anyone violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor
and upon conviction shall be fined in any sum not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(1962 Code, art. 20, secs. 2–4)
Sec. 12.06.072 Greenville Road
(a) No person shall operate a motor vehicle along Greenville Road from Houston Street to F.M. 35 with a
carrying capacity greater than one (1) ton, except for the purpose of making commercial deliveries.
(b) The mayor is hereby authorized to have traffic signs displaying the appropriate designation placed along
Greenville Road from Houston Street to F.M. 35.
(c) Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon
conviction, be subject to a fine of not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00).
(Ordinance 131, secs. 1-3, adopted 7/17/84)
Sec. 12.06.073 Houston Street
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person as driver or owner to operate any vehicle weighing over 20,000 pounds
on Houston Street between Highway 66 and Old Greenville Road. (Ordinance 174, secs. 1, 2, adopted 9/16/86)
(b) The city manager is hereby authorized to post the appropriate signs giving notice to the traveling public of
the provisions contained in subsection (a) of this section. (Ordinance 174, secs. 1, 2, adopted 9/16/86; Ordinance
adopting Code)
CHAPTER 13
UTILITIES
ARTICLE 13.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS*
Division 1. Water Wells
Sec. 13.01.001 Private water well registration
(a) All existing private water wells constructed by a person other than the city and located within the city's
incorporated boundaries must be registered with the city. Owners of unregistered water wells, existing prior to
the enactment of this section, must register the private water well with the city by submitting the following
information to the city manager:
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 427/652
(1) The name of the owner of the land upon which the well is located;
(2) The exact location of the well identified by latitude and longitude on a USGS 7.5-inch
topographic map;
(3) The size of the lot on which the well is located (measured in acres); and
(4) The identification of any recorded municipal setting designations within one-half mile of the
well.
(b) Registration fees shall be fifty dollars ($50.00).
Sec. 13.01.002 Permit required to drill, repair, abandon, or plug water well
It shall be unlawful for any person to drill, construct, repair, correct, abandon, or plug a water well or to engage
in such work within the city's incorporated boundaries, without first securing a permit from the city.
Sec. 13.01.003 Application for permit
(a) Any person requiring a private water well permit as required herein shall file with the city a written
application, not less than thirty (30) days prior to the commencement of the work. Such application shall contain
the following information:
(1) The name of the owner of the land upon which the work is to be done;
(2) The exact location of the well identified by latitude and longitude on a USGS 7.5-inch
topographic map;
(3) The size of the lot on which the well is located (measured in acres);
(4) The depth of the well to be drilled, repaired, or plugged;
(5) A complete set of plans and specifications for the work to be done sealed by a licensed
professional engineer;
(6) The name and address of the contractor;
(7) The name, address, and state license number of the professional engineer or geologist;
(8) The location of the nearest public water supply; and
(9) The identification of any record municipal setting designations within one-half mile of the
proposed new well.
(b) Application fees shall be one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00).
Sec. 13.01.004 Issuance of permit
Application for a private water well permit shall be made in writing to the building official. The building official
may grant a private water well permit if, after review of the application and investigation of any other pertinent
issues or matters, the building official finds:
(1) That the lot size on which the water well is to be drilled is not less than five acres;
(2) That the water well will be used solely for agricultural, solely for irrigation purposes, or solely
used for a combination of agricultural and irrigation purposes; and
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 428/652
(3) That the drilling of the water well by the applicant will not at the time or in the future in any
way affect, diminish or interfere with the city's public water supply system.
Sec. 13.01.005 Additional permits
It shall be unlawful for any applicant who obtains a permit to construct a private water well of a certain depth, to
extend such well to a depth exceeding the depth provided for in such permit without first obtaining an additional
permit from the city.
Sec. 13.01.006 Interconnection or cross connection with city water
It shall be unlawful to construct, allow or permit any interconnection or cross connection between the city's
public water supply systems and any private water well registered or authorized by permit as required herein.
(Ordinance 10-12-802 adopted 12/14/10; Ordinance 11-03-818 adopted 3/8/11)
ARTICLE 13.02 BILLING AND ACCOUNT PROCEDURES
Sec. 13.02.001 Penalty
Any person, firm, corporation or business entity violating this article, as it exists or may be amended, shall be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine not to exceed the sum of
five hundred dollars ($500.00), unless the violation relates to fire safety, zoning or public health and sanitation,
including dumping of refuse, in which case the fine shall not exceed the sum of two thousand and no/100 dollars
($2,000.00). Each continuing day's violation under this article shall constitute a separate offense. The penal
provisions imposed under this article shall not preclude the city from filing suit to enjoin the violation. The city
retains all legal rights and remedies available to it pursuant to local, state and federal law. (Ordinance 06-08-518,
sec. 3, adopted 8/8/06)
Sec. 13.02.002 Method of payment; returned checks
Utility bill payments may be made by cash, check or money order. No two-party checks will be accepted. No
payroll checks will be cashed through the utility department. All returned checks will be assessed a handling fee
of thirty dollars ($30.00) for administrative costs. This handling fee will also be charged to customers requesting
the city to re-present a check for deposit. The city will re-present a check only one time. Only cash, a cashier's
check or a money order will be accepted for payment after three (3) returned checks have been received by the
city over a two-year period, using the date of the last returned check. (Ordinance 06-08-518, sec. 3(1)(a),
adopted 8/8/06)
Sec. 13.02.003 Refund or transfer of deposit
(a) Except as otherwise provided herein, all water deposits are nontransferable and are refunded only at the
time service is terminated provided the subject account has no balance then owed to the city.
(b) A customer moving out of the city and having no balance owed on the city utility account may transfer
their water deposit to another person living at the same dwelling at the time the customer moves out by sending
a letter, dated and signed by the original applicant who tendered the water deposit, requesting said transfer. Upon
completion of the required forms and payment of any required fees, the transferee may have the service at the
subject address transferred into their name.
(Ordinance 06-08-518, sec. 3(1)(b), (f), adopted 8/8/06)
Sec. 13.02.004 Rereading of meter
A customer may request a reread of their water meter. A special meter reading charge of seven dollars and fifty
cents ($7.50) shall be charged on the next month's water bill if the reading is determined to be correct. No
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 429/652
reading charge will be assessed if the city determines that the original reading was incorrect. (Ordinance 06-08-
518, sec. 3(1)(c), adopted 8/8/06)
Sec. 13.02.005 Testing of meter
A customer may request their water meter be sent off-site to determine if the meter is reading properly. A special
meter test charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged on the next month's water bill if the test results
indicate, as determined by the city, that the meter is in good working condition. No meter test fee will be
assessed if the city determines that the meter is not operating within ten percent (10%) of the calibrated range of
a properly functioning meter. (Ordinance 06-08-518, sec. 3(1)(d), adopted 8/8/06)
Sec. 13.02.006 Time frame for connection of service
If the city receives the service application, payment of all required deposits and a copy of the certificate of
occupancy/certificate of home occupancy inspection by 4:00 p.m. on a regular business day, all reasonable
efforts will be made to connect utility service by the end of the same business day. Otherwise, all reasonable
efforts will be made to connect service by the end of the following business day. (Ordinance 06-08-518, sec. 3(1)
(e), adopted 8/8/06)
Sec. 13.02.007 Tampering with or bypassing meter
(a) The city will prosecute persons who tamper with or bypass a water meter that has been turned off and/or
locked. Tampering with or bypassing a meter shall be prosecuted in accordance with the Code of Criminal
Procedure and/or the Penal Code, as they exist or may be amended.
(b) In addition to any other remedies the city may have, the customer will be billed for expenses for damage
to, replacement of, destruction of or misuse of the city's equipment and for water and sewer services not
recorded on the customer's meter by reason of the tampering or service diversion at the appropriate rate (the
amount of which may be estimated by the city from the best available data). Such expenses may be added to the
customer's utility bill.
(Ordinance 08-11-689 adopted 11/11/08)
Sec. 13.02.008 Adjustments to bills
(a) Generally. Any scaling or reduction of any city utility bill as shown by a meter is unlawful and is
prohibited, unless such reduction is made in accordance with specific provisions of this article. Any officer or
employee of the city scaling or reducing any utility bill, except in accordance with this article, shall be
personally responsible for the reduction in the bill, and shall be dismissed from the city's service therefor.
(Ordinance 10-08-790, sec. 1, adopted 8/10/10)
(b) Adjustment of wastewater usage as a result of defect in customer's line.
(1) Any residential, commercial, multifamily or outdoor customer of the city, who has been a
customer at such location for at least six (6) months, may request a correction of any city utility bill
submitted to him/it by the city for sewage usage because of a loss of water through an excusable
defect (hereinafter defined) in the customer's water line for a period not to exceed three (3)
consecutive months, by filing a sworn written application with the utility official, as designated by
the city, and mailing or delivering the same to the department within six (6) months of the repair of
the excusable defect. Such application shall contain the following matters and such other information
as the utility official may require:
(A) The name of the applicant, the address or description of the property or premises
furnished water, the bill which is sought to be corrected, the date of the bill and the period of
water usage covered thereby.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 430/652
(B) A statement of the date on which the excusable defect in the applicant's water line was
discovered, and the date on which it was repaired, and a statement that water was lost after
passing through the city water meter serving such property and that such water was not used in
any manner by anyone.
(C) A written acknowledgment that the applicant makes the statements shown on the
application and swears to their veracity for the purpose of inducing the city to grant a reduction
in the amount of the utility bill for which a correction is requested.
(D) The application shall show whether or not there have been any additional water
appliances placed in use on the applicant's premises during the period covered by such bill.
(E) Documentation shall be submitted detailing the exact nature and date of repairs to the
applicant's water line. Documentation shall also be submitted that includes an analysis of
whether or not loss water entered the wastewater collection system.
(F) A statement that the applicant is personally familiar with all of the matters of facts stated
in the application and sworn to therein, that they are made on his personal knowledge and that
they are each true and correct.
(G) The customer shall execute a statement setting forth an understanding that the application
is a government record subject to criminal prosecution for false statements under chapter 37 of
the Texas Penal Code and shall state that the applicant certifies that the application contains no
false statements.
As used in this article, the term excusable defect shall mean a rupture or leakage of the
customer's water lines as may be caused by freezing weather, settlement, corrosion, wear or
accident. The term does not apply to defective or out-of-repair faucets.
(2) Applications under this subsection shall be made on forms prescribed by the director of public
works and engineering.
(3) Upon receipt of a properly completed application, the utility official shall review such
application, and, if the utility official approves the same as being in compliance with this article, the
applicant's account shall be corrected in the following manner:
(A) If the applicant has a winter average, as that term is defined in section 13.03.002(c) of
this code, and applicant's loss of water through an excusable defect did not occur in the months
of December, January or February, then no adjustment will be made;
(B) If the applicant does not have a winter average, as that term is defined in section
13.03.002(c) of this code, then:
(i) The average of the applicant's water usage for either the five (5) months preceding
the month where there was a loss of water through an excusable defect or all months the
applicant's account has been active when there was no excusable defect, whichever is less,
will be the sewage usage billed to the customer for such month in dispute. Such average
shall be known as the “adjusted sewage usage” for such month in dispute; and
(ii) If the applicant's loss of water through an excusable defect did occur in the months
of December, January or February, then the adjusted sewage usage for such month in
dispute will be used to compute the winter average as that term is defined in section
13.03.002(c) of this code; or
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 431/652
(C) If the applicant has a winter average, as that term is defined in section 13.03.002(c) of
this code, and the applicant's loss of water through an excusable defect did occur in the months
of December, January or February, then:
(i) The average of the applicant's water usage for the five (5) months preceding the
month where there was a loss of water through an excusable defect shall be known as the
“adjusted sewage usage” for such month in dispute; and
(ii) The adjusted sewage usage for such month in dispute will be used to compute the
winter average as that term is defined in section 13.03.002(c) of this code.
(D) A determination by the utility official of the amount of a correction to be made in an
applicant's sewage bill in accordance with the provisions of this article shall be final.
(Ordinance 11-10-854, sec. 3, adopted 9/13/11)
(c) Billing error disputes. Any residential, commercial, multifamily or outdoor customer of the city who
thinks there is an error on the customer's water bill must report such error in writing to the utility department
within 60 days after the city sends the customer the water bill on which the error first appears. Failure to notify
the city in the period and manner set forth in this subsection may result in denial of the customer's claim. If the
city fails to make a determination within 60 days on the validity of the alleged error submitted by the customer
as set forth in this section, the customer's claim will be deemed valid. (Ordinance 10-06-777 adopted 6/8/10)
Sec. 13.02.009 Late fee; cutoff notice; reconnect fee
(a) Late fee. Payments made after the 15th of each month will be assessed a late fee of ten dollars ($10.00). If
the 15th of the month falls on Saturday, Sunday or a city-approved holiday, the ten dollar ($10.00) late fee will
not be assessed until after 5:00 p.m. of the next business day.
(b) Cutoff notice. Cutoff notices will be mailed to the customer once the ten dollar ($10.00) late fee has been
assessed. To avoid disconnection of service, all payments are due by 5:00 p.m. on the 26th of each month unless
the 26th falls on Saturday, Sunday or a city-approved holiday, and then the last day to pay to avoid disconnection
will be moved to 5:00 p.m. of the next business day.
(c) Reconnect fee during nonbusiness hours. If service requires disconnection for nonpayment of an account
owing up to three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00), the customer shall pay a thirty-five dollar ($35.00) fee, in
addition to the entire bill, to resume service to the account. If service requires disconnection for nonpayment of
an account owing more than three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00), the customer shall pay a reconnect fee in the
amount of 10 percent of the entire bill, in addition to the entire bill, to resume service to the account. Any
connection required to be made after 5:00 p.m. will require an additional connection charge of fifty dollars
($50.00).
(Ordinance 11-04-822 adopted 4/12/11)
Sec. 13.02.010 Termination of service for nonpayment
(a) Water service will not be turned off for nonpayment if reasonable effort to pay one-half (1/2) of the water
bill and/or arrangements with the water-billing clerk have been made for the remaining amount; however, the ten
dollar ($10.00) late fee described in section 13.02.009 will be required due to the bill not being paid by 5:00 p.m.
on the 15th of the month.
(b) Should a customer fail to pay for their water service in accordance with this article and the subject
statement for services, the city will send a certified letter to the customer at the subject address stating the date
the city intends to disconnect water utilities for failure to pay for the services, and who the customer can contact
at the city to schedule a hearing if they wish to dispute the amount of the charges or the decision to disconnect.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 432/652
The customer must request a hearing in writing within five (5) business days of receipt of the letter. If the
customer requests a hearing, the hearing will be scheduled before the intended disconnection date set forth in the
city's letter. The hearing will be held before an officer or employee of the city who has the authority to resolve
the dispute and rescind the disconnection order if the hearing results in a finding that the disconnection order
was issued in error. If the customer fails to request a hearing, or a hearing is held and it is determined that the
order to disconnect is valid, then the city may disconnect the services on the date set forth in the letter. The city
will not terminate water service for nonpayment on Fridays.
(Ordinance 06-08-518, sec. 3(4), adopted 8/8/06)

charge. (Ordinance 09-10-743 adopted 10/13/09)
(c) Averaging of bills.
(1) Except as provided by subsection (2) below, each year during the month of March, a winter
average will be computed for each customer by averaging the actual usage of water during the
preceding months of December, January, and February. The winter average will be used to compute
the bills beginning with the April billing and continuing through March of the following year.
(2) If the customer did not receive service during the preceding December, January, and February,
or if there are other factual reasons that make it impractical to use the months of December, January
and February to compute a winter average pursuant to subsection (1) above, then the wastewater
usage will be computed based on a minimum of 3,000 gallons for wastewater or 50% of the actual
water usage, whichever amount is greater for each month.
(3) If pursuant to section 13.02.008(b)(3)(B) of this code the customer has been issued an adjusted
sewage usage for the immediately preceding month(s) of December, January and/or February, then
the adjusted sewage usage for such month shall be used in lieu of the actual usage for such month to
calculate the winter average in subsection (1) above.
(Ordinance 11-10-854, sec. 4, adopted 9/13/11)
Sec. 13.03.003 Meter fees
Water meter fees shall be as provided in section 1.05.065 of this code. (Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 13.03.004 Deposit
(a) There is hereby established a security deposit fee which shall be paid prior to the commencement of water
service, sewer service or solid waste and recyclable materials collection service by the city or its designated
contractor. Prior to water services, sewer services or solid waste and recyclable materials collection services
being provided, an application for such service shall be made to the city and the utility deposit fee provided
herein paid. Such fee is in addition to all other fees as may be fixed and established from time to time by the city,
and the fee herein established is for securing the faithful payment for such utility services.
(b) The utility deposit fees provided for herein are as follows:
(1) Residential water: $100.00.
(2) Nonresidential water: $175.00.
(3) Transit meter: $2,500.00.
(c) Deposits will be returned after two years' on-time payment history is established, upon request by the
customer.
(d) In the event that water is disconnected for nonpayment, the adequacy of the deposit will be reevaluated
and may be increased. The maximum deposit assessed will not exceed three times the average monthly bill for
the customer.
(Ordinance 06-12-547, sec. 3, adopted 12/19/06)
Sec. 13.03.005 Emergency notification fee

ARTICLE 13.04 SOLID WASTE*
Division 1. Generally
Sec. 13.04.001 Title; definitions
(a) This article shall be known as the garbage ordinance of the city.
(b) The word “premises” as used in this article shall be taken to mean business houses, offices, theaters,
hotels, restaurants, cafes, eating houses, tourist camps, apartments, sanitariums, rooming houses, schools, private
residences, vacant lots, hospitals and all other places within the city limits where garbage, trash or rubbish
accumulates in ordinary quantities.
(c) The various kinds of garbage shall be defined as follows:
Dry kitchen refuse. The solids after the liquid or slop has been drained off.
Kitchen garbage. Dry kitchen refuse, all meat, vegetable and fruit refuse, small dead animals and dead fowls,
from any premises within the city limits.
Rubbish. Tin cans, bottles, glass, scraps of iron, tin, wire, or any other metals from any premises within the city
limits.
Trash. Paper of all kinds, rags, old clothing, paper containers, old rubber, pieces of wood, boxes, barrels, crates,
feathers, weeds, grass, or tree limbs from any premises within the city limits.
(1962 Code, art. 27, sec. 1)
Sec. 13.04.002 Penalty
Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined in any sum not more than $100.00, and each such day violation
continues shall constitute a separate offense. (1962 Code, art. 27, sec. 17)
Sec. 13.04.003 Provisions cumulative
This article shall be cumulative of all other sanitary ordinances or regulations of the city unless in conflict with
the terms of said ordinances and regulations, in which case the terms of this article shall prevail. (1962 Code, art.
27, sec. 18)
Sec. 13.04.004 Receptacles required; location for placement of waste for collection
It shall be the duty of every person, firm or corporation owning, managing, operating, leasing or renting any
premises, or any place where kitchen garbage accumulates, to provide a portable garbage can constructed of
galvanized iron, tin or other suitable metal, with two handles and a tightfitting cover of a capacity of not less
than five gallons nor over thirty gallons, and the daily accumulation of kitchen garbage and dry kitchen refuse
shall be placed in this garbage can. It shall also be the duty of every person, firm or corporation owning,
managing, operating, leasing or renting any premises to place all trash and rubbish from said premises in boxes,
sacks or barrels or other receptacles of reasonable size, provided that the gross weight does not exceed 100
pounds. Garbage cans, boxes, sacks or barrels of trash and rubbish and tree limbs (which shall be cut into
lengths not exceeding four feet) shall be placed inside the property line at the edge of the alley where there is no
fence; where there is a back fence with an alley gate, garbage cans, boxes, sacks or barrels of trash, rubbish and
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 438/652
tree limbs (which shall be cut into lengths not exceeding four feet) shall be placed against the inside of the fence
at the side of the alley gate; if there is no alley gate, there shall be built a platform against the inside of the fence
below the top of the fence so that garbage collection vehicles can drive close up to the fence and lift the garbage,
trash and rubbish over the fence; and, where there is no alley, kitchen garbage, trash and rubbish shall be placed
inside the curbline of street, to be collected by the city garbage vehicles. (1962 Code, art. 27, sec. 2)
Sec. 13.04.005 Time for placement and removal of receptacles
(a) Requirements. The city adopts the following residential refuse collection procedures:
(1) It shall be the duty of the owner, manager, tenant or occupant of any dwelling, building or
premises to place all receptacles containing household and commercial refuse at the designated point
of collection no earlier than 5 p.m. of the day before collection.
(2) It shall be the duty of the owner, manager, tenant or occupant of any dwelling, building or
premises to remove all reusable receptacles from the collection point by 10 p.m. the same day as the
collection except where such receptacles may be stored in alleys designated for refuse collection.
Receptacles not removed shall be declared a public nuisance and may be removed by the city.
(b) Noncompliance. Noncompliance with residential refuse collection procedures shall be deemed a public
nuisance, and it shall be unlawful for any person to cause or maintain any such public nuisance. Proof of
requirement of a culpable mental state is not required in the prosecution of an offense under this section.
(c) Notice of violation. Whenever any such public nuisance exists on any dwelling, building or premises
within the city limits it is in violation of this section. Beginning May 14, 2003, and ending at midnight, August
15, 2003, notices will be given concerning such violation(s).
(d) Issuance of citation; penalty. If the owner, manager, tenant or occupant of any dwelling, building or
premises on which the nuisance is located does not remove or abate such public nuisance, the code enforcement
officer shall cause to be prepared, filed in the municipal court and served upon the defendant named therein a
written citation charging such owner, manager, tenant or occupant of any dwelling, building or premises with the
violation of maintaining a public nuisance. The first violation fine is $25.00, doubling each violation up to
$200.00. Upon finding that any owner, manager, tenant or occupant is guilty of maintaining a public nuisance as
set forth in this section, such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine not
to exceed $200.00, and each day and every day that such public nuisance is maintained shall constitute a
separate and distinct offense. The penal provisions imposed under this section shall not preclude the city from
filing suit to enjoin the violation. The city retains all legal rights and remedies available to it pursuant to local,
state and federal law.
(Ordinance 03-05-336, secs. 2–5, adopted 5/6/03)
Sec. 13.04.006 Improper preparation or placement of waste for collection
The city garbage department will not make collection of kitchen garbage, trash or rubbish or tree limbs where
same is not prepared for collection and placed as designated by the terms of this article, and failure to comply
with this provision will be an offense and each day's failure to comply will constitute a separate offense. (1962
Code, art. 27, sec. 7)
Sec. 13.04.007 Depositing waste in street or alley
The placing of kitchen garbage, trash or rubbish or any article, thing or material in any street or alley within the
city limits is prohibited. (1962 Code, art. 27, sec. 8)
Sec. 13.04.008 Receptacles to be kept in sanitary condition; prevention of waste from scattering
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 439/652
Garbage cans shall be kept in sanitary condition and closed tightly, and lime must be used at places where
receptacles for the garbage, trash and rubbish are located to be collected by the city garbage department to keep
down odors and flies. The contents of all receptacles shall be so protected that the wind cannot blow out and
scatter same over the streets, alleys and premises of the city. (1962 Code, art. 27, sec. 14)
Sec. 13.04.009 Frequency of collection
(a) In the business district and from hotels, restaurants, cafes and boarding houses, collections will be made
twice weekly.
(b) In the residential districts, kitchen garbage shall be prepared for collection to be made one time per week,
or as often as may be necessary to comply with sanitary regulations of the city; trash and rubbish shall be
prepared for one collection per week, the time of such collections to be announced by the designated official.
(1962 Code, art. 27, sec. 15)
Sec. 13.04.010 Places of wholesale accumulations
The places of wholesale accumulations, such as killing and dressing plants for fowl, wholesale fruit and
vegetable houses, storage and other places where the daily accumulation of kitchen garbage, trash or rubbish is
more than the ordinary quantities, are not included in the service furnished by the city garbage department, and
such places are required to remove same at their own expense, in the manner and by the method directed by the
official designated by the governing body of the city. (1962 Code, art. 27, sec. 3; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 13.04.011 Heavy dead animals
Heavy dead animals, such as cows, horses and mules, shall be disposed of at the expense of the owner or person
having same in charge in the manner and by the method directed by the designated official. (1962 Code, art. 27,
sec. 4; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 13.04.012 Bricks, lumber and other heavy material
Heavy accumulations such as brick, broken concrete, lumber, ashes, clinkers, cinders, dirt and plaster, sand or
gravel, automobile frames, dead trees and other bulky, heavy material shall be disposed of at the expense of
owner or person controlling same under the direction of the designated official. (1962 Code, art. 27, sec. 5)
Sec. 13.04.013 Manure; waste oil
Manure from cow lots, horse stables, poultry yards, and pigeon lofts, and waste oils from garages or filling
stations, shall be disposed of at the expense of the party responsible for same under the direction of the
designated official. (1962 Code, art. 27, sec. 6)
Sec. 13.04.014 Unlawful disposal
The disposal of kitchen garbage, trash or rubbish and that designated under sections 13.04.011, 13.04.012, and
13.04.013 of this article or any kind of rubbish in any place within the city limits is prohibited. (1962 Code, art.
27, sec. 9; Ordinance adopting Code)
Sec. 13.04.015 Depositing waste in another's receptacle
(a) Definitions. In this section:
Garbage. Any and all decayable waste from a public or private establishment, residence, or restaurant, including
animal and vegetable waste material.
Litter. Garbage, refuse and rubbish as defined herein.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 440/652
Premises. All publicly and privately owned property within the territorial limits of the city, including vacant land
or a building designed or used for residential, commercial, business, industrial, government, education, or
religious purposes. The term includes a yard, ground, walk, driveway, or other structure appurtenant to the
property.
Refuse. All putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes,
street cleaning, dead animals, and solid market and industrial wastes.
Rubbish. Nondecayable waste, except ashes, from a public or private establishment, residence, or restaurant that
consists of:
(1) Combustible waste material, including paper, rags, cartons, wood, excelsior, furniture, rubber,
plastics, yard trimmings, leaves, or similar materials;
(2) Noncombustible waste material, including glass, crockery, tin or aluminum cans, metal
furniture, and similar materials;
(3) Discarded or worn-out manufactured materials and machinery, including motor vehicles and
parts of motor vehicles, tires, aircraft, farm implements, building or construction materials,
appliances, and scrap metal.
(b) Permission required.
(1) It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit any litter into a garbage can, receptacle
or dumpster located on the premises of another person without first obtaining permission to do so
from that person.
(2) A person is presumed to have not first obtained permission from the person on whose premises
the garbage can, receptacle or dumpster is located if the garbage can, receptacle or dumpster is
placarded to indicate no private/unauthorized dumping.
(3) It is a defense to prosecution that the person charged produces verifiable proof to the court that
the person on whose premises the garbage can, receptacle or dumpster was located had given
permission to dispose of the type of litter that was disposed of by the person charged.
(c) Penalty. Any person found violating any provision of this section, and upon conviction thereof, shall be
punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred and no/100 dollars ($500.00), except if the violation was found to
be committed intentionally, knowingly, recklessly, or with criminal negligence, then the person shall be punished
by a fine not exceeding two thousand and no/100 dollars ($2,000.00). Each continuing day's violation under this
section shall constitute a separate offense. The penal provisions imposed under this section shall not preclude the
city from filing suit to enjoin the violation. The city retains all legal rights and remedies available to it pursuant
to local, state and federal law.
(Ordinance 08-02-643, sec. 2, adopted 2/13/08)
Sec. 13.04.016 Meddling with receptacles or contents
Meddling with garbage cans, trash or rubbish receptacles or in any way pilfering, scattering contents or junking
in any alley or street within the city limits is prohibited. (1962 Code, art. 27, sec. 10)
Sec. 13.04.017 Brush
The city manager shall develop written policies/procedures regarding the time, frequency, and manner of brush
pick-up. Such policies/procedures shall be made available at city hall and posted on the city's website.
(Ordinance 12-08-906, sec. 3, adopted 8/28/12)

ARTICLE 13.05 WATER AND SEWER EXTENSIONS
Division 1. Generally
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 442/652
Secs. 13.05.001–13.05.030 Reserved
Division 2. Pro Rata Charge
Sec. 13.05.031 Purpose and intent
(a) The intent and purpose of these rules and regulations is to provide an equitable charge for water and sewer
connections in the city on a front-foot basis as a proportional distribution of the cost of water and sewer main
extensions to serve property not previously served with standard mains and provide a contribution to be
uniformly enforced against all property.
(b) It is recognized that each property has its individual problems and that no fixed rules will apply to all
cases; therefore, final approval of all or any part of any plans rests with the city. In all cases, the size mains for
adequate service shall be determined by the city council or its delegated authority, and his decision will be final.
(c) No person shall acquire any vested rights under the terms and provisions of these rules and regulations.
(Ordinance 134, sec. 1, adopted 9/4/84)
Sec. 13.05.032 Definitions
For the purpose of this division, the following definitions shall apply exclusively:
Applicant. The owner of a lot or tract of land, or his agent, requesting water or sanitary sewer service.
City. Royse City, Texas, a municipal corporation, acting by and through its governing body.
Consumer. The actual user of water or sanitary sewer service from a city connection.
Developer. The owner or agent of the owner subdividing lots or tracts for sale or lease as homes, apartments,
commercial shopping centers or industrial sites.
Engineer. The city engineer or his duly authorized assistants, agents, engineers or superintendents, acting within
the scope of the particular duties entrusted them.
Evaluated cost. The latest evaluated cost as established by the City of Dallas, Texas, under section 49-69 of the
Dallas City Code or similar succeeding ordinance.
Front footage. The number of linear feet in that portion of the boundary of a property abutting a street, alley or
easement containing a water and sanitary sewer “distribution main” from which the property will be served with
water and sewer service.
Individual owner. A person requesting extension of water or sewer service to a property which will be used as
his own residence or business; or an individual commercial or industrial concern requesting extension of water
or sewer service to property to be used for its own operation, which property or a portion thereof will not be
sold, leased or rented in connection with its intended function.
Property. Any lot, abstract or parcel of land.
Property owner. The record title holder of premises served or to be served with a connection to a water or sewer
main.
Pro rata. A portion of the cost of water or sewer main extensions to serve the owner's property based upon the
front footage and area to be served. The amount of these charges per front foot and area is stated in these rules
and regulations.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 443/652
Side mains. Water or sewer mains which lie along one or more sides of a subdivision and serve adjacent property
other than that for which the extension was made.
Standard size sewer main. A sanitary sewer main six (6) or eight (8) inches in diameter with appurtenances, as
determined by the city.
Standard size water main. A water main six (6) or eight (8) inches in diameter with appurtenances and
adequately supported by water mains large enough to provide standard fire protection as recognized by the
National Board of Fire Underwriters. The size of the main will be determined by the city.
Superintendent of waterworks. The superintendent of the city waterworks, or his duly authorized assistants or
agents.
(Ordinance 134, sec. 2, adopted 9/4/84)
Sec. 13.05.033 Penalty
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision of this division, and any person violating any
provision of this division shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be subject
to a fine in an amount not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00), and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ordinance 134, sec. 8, adopted
9/4/84)
Sec. 13.05.034 Extensions and charges for individual owners
(a) Upon request by an eligible applicant and receipt of payment of charges due, the city may, at its option,
extend or cause to be extended water and sewer mains in the streets, alleys or easements within the boundary of
the city to permit connection by individual property owners.
(b) Charges shall be made against the owner of the property whose water and sewer lines are to be connected
to the city's mains at the following rates:
(1) The evaluated cost of a standard size water or sewer main for those water and sewer main
extensions required to reach a front corner of the property for which application has been made.
(2) One-half the evaluated cost of a standard size water and sewer main per front foot of the
property to which the water or sewer connection is to be made. This shall apply to all property
fronting on streets in areas platted into the usual rectangular lots or tracts of land.
(3) The lesser amount of $150.00 per connection or $300.00 per acre for water and $200.00 per
connection or $300.00 per acre for sewer except as noted in subsection (f) of this section.
(c) On property intended to be used for single residential or duplex purposes with a depth greater than 150 feet
from the front street line, the following shall apply:
(1) If the property is later subdivided and an application is made for an extension of water and/or
sewer mains for additional service to the property, the terms of this division shall apply to such
property as created.
(2) On property deeper than 260 feet that extends the distance between two street lines, the pro rata
charges provided in subsection (b)(2) of this section shall be paid on both frontages when a
connection is secured to the property.
(d) Where property is intended to be used for other than single residential or duplex purposes and has a depth
of greater than 150 feet from the street line, the rate in subsection (b)(2) of this section shall apply on the
frontage of all streets which the property may abut, less 150 feet frontage for each corner of the property
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 444/652
abutting a street intersection. Should such property be resubdivided whereby main extensions are required to
serve the same, the terms of this division shall apply.
(e) Where property is irregular in size or shape, the pro rata charge shall be based on the average frontage of
such property, or upon equivalent rectangular lots or tracts using one front foot for each 150 square feet of area,
whichever is less.
(f) Where unsubdivided tracts of land are to be developed as a unit for shopping centers, apartments, industrial
sites or other similar uses, the applicant shall pay pro rata charges on street frontage as outlined in subsection (d)
of this section and $300.00 per acre for water and $400.00 per acre for sewer. Any mains extended through or
into such tracts for service to individual buildings or leased space will be built at the applicant's expense in
accordance with city standards. Metering and service connections shall be built in accordance with city
standards.
(g) At the option of the city and in lieu of the front-foot charges and in addition to the connection or acreage
charge set forth in subsection (b)(3) of this section, the applicant may be allowed to extend or cause to be
extended water and sewer mains to and across the frontage of the property for which the application for service
has been made. The applicant must construct water and sewer mains across the entire frontage of the property
and must design and construct all such mains in accordance with city subdivision ordinances and construction
standards.
(h) The owners of any intervening property served by the mains extended under this division will be:
(1) Required to pay the pro rata charges provided by the rules and regulations at such time as their
property is connected to the mains thus laid.
(2) Considered connected to the mains at the time the mains are accepted by the city, even though
they may have temporary service.
(Ordinance 134, sec. 3, adopted 9/4/84)
Sec. 13.05.035 Replacement of substandard mains
(a) When property owners or customers request the replacement of a substandard size water main with a
standard size water main in order to provide fire protection, to increase the supply of water for consumption, or
to increase the water pressure for consumption, the city may construct a standard size water main upon the
payment of pro rata charges by a sufficient number of applicants to qualify for a main extension as provided in
this division.
(b) Whenever a substandard size water main must be replaced by a standard size water main in advance of
street paving, or to improve the water distribution system, the city may construct the standard size main in any
street, alley, or easement and transfer all service connections from the substandard size main or tie the
substandard main to the standard size main.
(c) Pro rata charges applicable to any property having service through or from the new standard size main
shall be due and payable upon such interconnection or reconnection.
(Ordinance 134, sec. 4, adopted 9/4/84)
Sec. 13.05.036 Extensions and charges for property to be subdivided or platted
(a) It shall be unlawful for any person to provide water and sewer service to any lot, tract or plot of land, or
any part thereof, unless and until such plan, plat or replat of such lot or tract of land has conformed to the
platting requirements of the city, has been approved by the city plan [city council] and has been filed for record
with the county. Pro rata charges must be paid before approval of the city of a plat, replat or plan will be granted.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 445/652
(b) Water and sewer mains may be extended within the property to be subdivided or platted for development
in accordance with the minimum standards and procedures described below:
(1) Where developers defray the entire cost of water and sewer mains within their subdivisions, the
city will refund the developer the difference between the evaluated cost of any water or sewer main
and the evaluated cost of the size line required to serve the subdivisions down to an eight-inch line.
(c) For water and sewer mains that lie along one or more sides of the property to be subdivided or platted for
development and:
(1) Where the developer has advanced the cost of such mains, refunds will be made as follows:
(A) For mains eight inches and smaller, one-half the evaluated cost per front foot of the
property that lies along the main.
(B) For mains larger than eight inches in size, the difference between the evaluated cost of
the main and one-half the evaluated cost of an eight-inch main or such larger sizes as are
required to serve the subdivision for which connections are made.
(2) Where the mains were laid or caused to be laid by the city, the developer will pay the city onehalf
the evaluated cost of an eight-inch main or such larger sizes as are required to serve the
subdivision.
(d) For off-site extensions required to serve the property to be subdivided or platted for developments and:
(1) Where the developer has advanced the cost of such mains, refunds will be made as follows:
(A) For mains eight inches and smaller, the evaluated cost per front foot of the property that
lies along the main.
(B) For mains larger than eight inches in size, the difference between the evaluated cost of
the main and the evaluated cost of an eight-inch main or such larger sizes as are required to
serve the subdivision for which connections are made.
(2) Where the mains were laid or caused to be laid by the city, the developer will pay the city onehalf
the evaluated cost of an eight-inch main or such larger sizes as are required to serve the
subdivision.
(e) At the option of the city and in lieu of the front-foot charges and in addition to the connection or acreage
charge set forth in section 13.05.034(b)(3), the applicant may be allowed to extend or cause to be extended water
and sewer mains to and across the frontage of the property for which the application for service has been made.
The applicant must construct water and sewer mains across the entire frontage of the property and must design
and construct all such mains in accordance with city subdivision ordinances and construction standards.
(Ordinance 134, sec. 5, adopted 9/4/84)
Sec. 13.05.037 Refunds
(a) In no event shall the city be obligated to proceed under the terms of this division if funds are not available
for the administration of the refunds as set forth in this division.
(b) Refunds, when due in accordance with subsection (c) of this section, will be made upon acceptance of the
system by the city and receipt of an itemization of the refunds for which the application was made.
(c) When any property for which an applicant has advanced the cost of water and sewer main extensions is
connected to the main extension, then the pro rata charges collected for the frontage of the connecting property
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 446/652
shall be refunded by the city to the applicant who originally advanced the cost of the main extension. After ten
years from the date the main extension was made, no further refunds will be made to the original applicant and
any funds deposited by the applicant and any subsequent pro rata refunds shall be placed in the city's general
operating fund.
(Ordinance 134, sec. 6, adopted 9/4/84)
Sec. 13.05.038 Fees for existing mains
(a) Prior to an extension from or connection to an existing or proposed water or sewer main which is or will
be located within property to be subdivided, the developer shall pay the city the total evaluated cost of a standard
size water or sewer main. If an existing or proposed water or sewer main is or will be located adjacent to a tract
of land to be subdivided, the developer shall pay one-half the total evaluated cost of a standard size water or
sewer main.
(b) If platted lots front an existing water transmission main and connection to the main from the lots is not
permitted by the city, the total evaluated cost shall not be charged if a developer installs a water main to serve
the lots. If platted lots back an existing water main and a duplicate water main which fronts the lots is installed
by a developer, the total evaluated cost shall not be charged the developer on the back water main.
(c) If a water or sewer main is less than standard size, the developer shall replace the substandard main with a
main of adequate size for permanent service as determined by the city or shall pay the total evaluated cost for the
replacement distance of the main.
(d) The city shall consider charges due from a developer for existing or proposed mains serving the
development as a setoff against refunds due a developer for installing mains in the development. If charges
exceed refunds, the developer shall pay the difference to the city prior to the beginning of water or sanitary
sewer service. If refunds exceed charges, the city shall make the refunds in accordance with provisions in
sections 13.05.036 and 13.05.037 of this division.
(Ordinance 134, sec. 7, adopted 9/4/84)
ARTICLE 13.06 CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL*
Sec. 13.06.001 Definitions
In this article:
Air gap. A physical separation between the free flowing discharge end of a potable water supply piping or
appurtenance and an open or nonpressure receiving vessel, plumbing fixture or other device. An approved airgap
separation shall be at least twice the diameter of the supply pipe measured vertically above the overflow rim
of the vessel, plumbing fixture or other device in no case less than one inch.
Approved backflow prevention assembly or backflow assembly or assembly. An assembly to prevent
backpressures or prevent backsiphonage and which is listed as an approved assembly by the University of
Southern California (USC) Foundation for Cross-Connection Control and Hydraulic Research or similar rating
or standards organization recognized by the managing director.
Approved fire sprinkler contractor. A person or entity holding a certificate of registration as such issued by the
state fire marshal's office.
Atmospheric vacuum breaker backflow prevention device or atmospheric vacuum breaker or AVB. A device used
to prevent backsiphonage in nonhealth hazard conditions. This device cannot be tested and cannot prevent
backpressure backflow.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 447/652
Backflow. A flow in a direction opposite to the normal flow or the introduction of any foreign liquids, gases, or
substances into the public water system.
Boresight or boresight to daylight. Providing adequate drainage for backflow prevention assemblies installed in
vaults through the use of an unobstructed drainpipe.
Contamination or contaminate. The entry into or presence in a public water supply system of any substance
which may be harmful to health or to the quality of the water.
Cross connection. Any physical arrangement where a potable water supply is connected, directly or indirectly
(actually or potentially), to or with any nonpotable water system or source, used water system or auxiliary water
supply, sewer, drain conduit, swimming pool, storage reservoir, plumbing fixture, evaporative coolers, airconditioner
units, fire protection system, or any other assembly which contains, or may contain, contaminated
water, sewage, or other liquid of unknown or unsafe quality which may be capable of imparting contamination
to the public water system as a result of backflow. Bypass arrangements, jumper connections, removable
sections, swivel or change-over assemblies, or other temporary or permanent assemblies through which, or
because of which, backflow may occur are considered to be cross connections.
Customer service inspection. An inspection designed to inspect and detect any actual or potential crossconnection
hazards and/or exceedance of the lead content levels in solder or flux, pipe or pipefittings.
Degree of hazard. The hazard classification (low or high) assigned to an actual or potential cross connection.
Double check detector backflow prevention assembly or double check detector or DCDA. An assembly
composed of a line-size approved double check assembly with bypass containing a specific water meter and an
approved double check valve assembly. The meter shall register accurately for very low rates of flow.
Double check valve backflow prevention assembly or double check assembly or double check. An assembly
which consists of two independently operating check valves which are spring-loaded or weighted, a gate valve
on each side of the checks, and test cocks to test the checks for tightness.
Fireline tester. A tester who is employed by an approved fire sprinkler contractor and is qualified to test
backflow prevention assemblies on firelines.
General tester or tester. A tester who is qualified to test backflow prevention assemblies on any domestic,
commercial, industrial or irrigation service except firelines. Recognized backflow prevention assembly testers
shall have completed a TCEQ Executive Director approved course on cross-connection control and backflow
prevention assembly testing, pass an examination administered by the TCEQ Executive Director, and hold a
current license as a backflow prevention assembly tester.
Health hazard. A cross connection or potential cross connection involving any substance that could, if
introduced into the potable water supply, cause death or illness, spread disease, or have a high probability of
causing such effects.
Inspector. A person who is recognized by the City of Garland as a licensed inspector under the provisions of this
article.
Managing director. The director of public works or other person appointed by the city manager.
Multifamily residential use. Water used by any residential customer of the water supply and includes duplexes,
multiplex, housing and apartments where the individual units are each on a separate meter; or, in cases where
two or more units are served by one meter, the units are full-time dwellings.
Nonhealth. The classification assigned to an actual or potential cross connection that may allow contamination
which may be objectionable but not hazardous to health to backflow into the public water system.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 448/652
Nonresidential use. Water used by any person other than a residential customer of the water supply and includes
all uses not specifically included in residential uses as defined in the city's comprehensive zoning ordinance.
Pollution hazard. An actual or potential threat to the physical properties of the water system or the potability of
the public or consumer's potable water system or the consumer's potable water system but which would not
constitute a health hazard. Maximum degree of intensity of pollution which the potable water system could be
degraded under this definition would cause a nuisance or be aesthetically objectionable or could cause damage
to the system or its appurtenances.
Potable water. Any water supply intended or used for human consumption or other domestic use.
Premises. Any real property to which water is provided, including all improvements, buildings, mobile and other
structures located on it.
Premises containment. Backflow prevention at the service connection between the public water system and the
water user.
Premises isolation. Backflow prevention at the point of use internally on the customer's premises.
Public water system or system. Any public or privately owned water system which supplies water for public
domestic use including all service lines, reservoirs, facilities, and any equipment used in the process of
producing, treating, storing or conveying water for public consumption.
Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly or reduced pressure principle assembly or RP
assembly or RP. An assembly containing two independently acting approved check valves, a hydraulicallyoperated,
mechanically independent pressure differential relief valve located between the check valves and at the
same time below the first check valve, and including properly located test cocks and tightly closing shut-off
valves at each end of the assembly.
Reduced pressure principle detector backflow prevention assembly or reduced pressure detector or RPDA. An
assembly composed of a line-size approved reduced pressure principle assembly with a bypass containing a
specific water meter and an approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly. The meter shall
register accurately for very low rates of flow.
Residential use. Water used by any residential customer of the water supply and includes single-family
dwellings.
Service connection. The point of delivery at which the public water system connects to the private supply line or
lateral of a water user.
Spill-resistant pressure vacuum breaker or SVB. An assembly containing an independently operating, internally
loaded check valve and independently operating, loaded air inlet valve located on the discharge side of the check
valve. This assembly is to be equipped with a properly located resilient seated test cock and tightly closing
resilient seated shut-off valves attached at each end of the assembly.
TCEQ. Texas Commission on Environmental Quality.
Thermal expansion. The natural change in volume of a confined quantity of water as a result of the raising of the
temperature of that water.
Used water. Water supplied by a public water system to a water user's system after it has passed through the
service connection.
Water use survey. A survey conducted or caused to be conducted by the local authority designed to identify any
possible source's of contamination to the potable water supply.
7/15/2019 https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0
https://z2codes.franklinlegal.net/franklin/PrintViewer.jsp?printCollection=0 449/652
Sec. 13.06.002 Backflow prevention assembly requirements
(a) With the approval of the managing director, a licensed cross-connection tester employed by or under
contract or registered with the city shall determine the type and location of any backflow assembly to be
installed within the city's water service area. The assembly shall be required in each of the following
circumstances, but the inspector is in no way limited to the following circumstances:
(1) When the nature and extent of any activity at a premises, or the materials or equipment used in
connection with any activity at a premises, or materials stored at a premises, could present a health
hazard upon entry into the public water system.
(2) When a premises has one or more cross connections.
(3) When internal cross connections are present that are not correctable.
(4) When intricate plumbing arrangements are present that make it impractical to ascertain whether
cross connections exist.
(5) When a premises has a repeated history of cross connections being established or reestablished.
(6) When entry to a premises is restricted so that inspections for cross connections cannot be made
with sufficient thoroughness or frequency to assure that cross connections do not exist.
(7) When materials are being used such that, if backflow should occur, a health hazard could result.
(8) When installation of an approved backflow prevention assembly is determined by an inspector
to be necessary to accomplish the purpose of these regulations.
(9) When an appropriate cross-connection survey report form (CST) has not been filed with the
managing director.
(10) On all multistory buildings or any building with a booster pump or elevated storage tank.
(11) For any used water return system that has received approval from the managing director.
(b) In all new nonresidential construction, the managing director has the authority to require an approved
